1→import { useState } from "react"; 2→ 3→const SOURCES = [ 4→ { 5→ title: "The 2028 Global Intelligence Crisis", 6→ author: "Citrini Research (with Alap Shah / LOTUS)", 7→ date: "February 22, 2026", 8→ url: "https://www.citriniresearch.com/p/2028gic", 9→ type: "Bear Thesis", 10→ color: "#E63946", 11→ format: "Future-dated post-mortem (written as if from June 2028)", 12→ keyThesis: "AI makes human intelligence abundant → white-collar displacement → consumption collapse → financial contagion → policy failure. Economy's institutions built for scarce human intelligence. Repricing is painful, disorderly, and investable.", 13→ chapters: [ 14→ "SaaS Compression: In-house AI becomes credible BATNA → 30% renewal discounts → ServiceNow cuts 15% workforce", 15→ "Friction Collapse: AI agents destroy habitual intermediation (DoorDash, travel, insurance) → stablecoins route around card interchange", 16→ "White-Collar Displacement: JOLTS professional services openings collapse → top 20% earners drive 65% spending → 2% job loss = 3-4% discretionary hit", 17→ "Ghost GDP: Productivity up, wages down → M2 velocity flatlines → labor share drops from 56% to 46%", 18→ "Financial Contagion: $2.5T private credit defaults → PE-insurance daisy chain (Apollo/Athene) → prime mortgages threatened", 19→ "Policy Trap: Government needs to transfer more while collecting less → traditional tools can't address structural cause", 20→ ], 21→ ourAssessment: "Direction plausible, speed compressed (5-8 years into 2). Underweights institutional drag, legal friction, deployment difficulty. 45% probability of 'Slow Grind' variant.", 22→ strengthsWeaknesses: { 23→ strengths: ["Strongest on financial contagion mechanics (PE-insurance-mortgage chain)", "Best articulation of 'Ghost GDP' concept", "Compelling on SaaS negotiation dynamics (BATNA framework)", "Gets the reflexive loop right: displacement → less spending → more displacement"], 24→ weaknesses: ["Timeline too compressed — institutional friction slows everything", "Mortgage crisis scenario requires faster income decline than plausible", "Underweights government response capacity (see: COVID stimulus speed)", "Assumes AI deployment is frictionless — ignores integration, trust, regulation"], 25→ }, 26→ }, 27→ { 28→ title: "Situational Awareness: The Decade Ahead", 29→ author: "Leopold Aschenbrenner (ex-OpenAI Superalignment team)", 30→ date: "June 2024", 31→ url: "https://situational-awareness.ai/", 32→ pdfUrl: "https://situational-awareness.ai/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/situationalawareness.pdf", 33→ type: "Capability Thesis", 34→ color: "#E9C46A", 35→ format: "165-page essay series (5 chapters + introduction)", 36→ keyThesis: "AGI by 2027 is strikingly plausible. GPT-2 to GPT-4 = preschooler to smart high-schooler in 4 years. Extrapolating compute + algorithmic efficiency trendlines = another equivalent jump by 2027. Then intelligence explosion → superintelligence. This triggers the most consequential geopolitical race in history.", 37→ chapters: [ 38→ "From GPT-4 to AGI: Counting the OOMs — ~0.5 OOMs/year compute + ~0.5 OOMs/year algorithmic efficiency + 'unhobbling' gains = AGI-level by 2027", 39→ "From AGI to Superintelligence: The Intelligence Explosion — Hundreds of millions of AGIs automate AI research → decade of progress compressed into ≤1 year", 40→ "The Challenges: IQ ≠ Reliability, 'unhobbling' still needed, but trendlines are relentless", 41→ "The Project: US government will inevitably nationalize/control AGI development → wartime-style mobilization", 42→ "Security & Geopolitics: China espionage threat is existential → current lab security is catastrophically inadequate", 43→ ], 44→ ourAssessment: "Capability trajectory largely validated by events since publication (Claude 3.5 → 4, o1/o3, Gemini 2.0). Timeline aggressive but defensible. Weaker on economic/social consequences — focuses on capability, not distribution.", 45→ strengthsWeaknesses: { 46→ strengths: ["Most rigorous capability extrapolation available", "Written by someone who was inside OpenAI — not speculating from outside", "OOMs framework gives falsifiable predictions", "Geopolitical analysis is sobering and underappreciated", "Now manages $1.5B fund — has skin in the game"], 47→ weaknesses: ["Almost entirely focused on capability, not economic/social distribution", "Assumes smooth scaling — doesn't account for potential plateaus (which have partially materialized)", "Geopolitical framing is US-centric and somewhat hawkish", "Doesn't address the 'who benefits?' question that Citrini tackles", "Written June 2024 — some predictions testable now"], 48→ }, 49→ }, 50→ { 51→ title: "The 2028 Global Intelligence Boom", 52→ author: "Michael X. Bloch", 53→ date: "February 22, 2026", 54→ url: "https://michaelxbloch.substack.com/p/the-2028-global-intelligence-boom", 55→ type: "Bull Rebuttal", 56→ color: "#2A9D8F", 57→ format: "Companion piece — same premise, same framework, opposite conclusion", 58→ keyThesis: "Same AI disruption happens, but the economy adapts faster than bears expect. Displaced workers + cheap AI tools = explosion of new business formation. Cost of starting a business falls 70-80%. Labor market doesn't stabilize because old jobs return — it stabilizes because new jobs that didn't have titles yet get created.", 59→ chapters: [ 60→ "SaaS repricing is real but not economic collapse — $500B bloated spend gets rationalized, spending redirects", 61→ "White-collar displacement is real but transitional (9 months, not 9 years) — recovery by Q3 2027", 62→ "New business formation explodes — 'minimum viable ambition' drops to near zero with AI tools", 63→ "Housing crisis doesn't materialize — incomes shift from corporate to entrepreneurial but recover in aggregate", 64→ "The 'AI-assisted' prefix: every professional services category gets augmented, not eliminated", 65→ ], 66→ ourAssessment: "This is essentially our 'New Guilds' variant (20% probability) + 'Bifurcation' variant (20%). Compelling counter-argument. The truth likely lives between Citrini's bear case and this bull case.", 67→ strengthsWeaknesses: { 68→ strengths: ["Directly addresses Citrini's weakest assumptions (permanent displacement, no adaptation)", "Historical precedent is on the bull side — economies do adapt", "The 'cost of starting a business falls 70-80%' observation is already happening", "Gets the Lucid Box thesis right — this is YOUR opportunity landscape"], 69→ weaknesses: ["Assumes adaptation happens smoothly and quickly — could be messier", "Doesn't address the financial contagion chain (Citrini's strongest argument)", "May underweight the speed of displacement vs. speed of adaptation", "Survivorship bias — focuses on success stories, not those who don't adapt"], 70→ }, 71→ }, 72→ { 73→ title: "AI as a Macro Shock: Income, Credit, and Convexity", 74→ author: "Arya Deniz", 75→ date: "February 22, 2026", 76→ url: "https://aryadeniz.substack.com/p/ai-as-a-macro-shock-income-credit", 77→ type: "Trade Expression", 78→ color: "#6D6875", 79→ format: "Macro analysis + bond trade thesis", 80→ keyThesis: "If abundant intelligence compresses earning power faster than politics can rebuild stability → demand fragility → growth scares → duration becomes convex. Long end of the yield curve is where the trade lives.", 81→ chapters: [ 82→ "Citrini's mechanism is explicit: intelligence cheaper → fewer workers → earnings compress → spending slows → loop tightens", 83→ "Present tense still looks deceptively ordinary — that's where macro pressure builds quietly", 84→ "Bond market as expression: demand fragility pulls forward growth scares, duration becomes convex", 85→ ], 86→ ourAssessment: "Useful for understanding how the thesis maps to actual tradeable instruments. Less relevant for our equity-focused portfolio but worth tracking for macro signals.", 87→ strengthsWeaknesses: { 88→ strengths: ["Best translation of thesis into actual trade mechanics", "Identifies the yield curve as the real-time signal of thesis validation"], 89→ weaknesses: ["Bond-focused — less applicable to our equity/crypto portfolio", "Assumes rates market will price displacement before equity market does"], 90→ }, 91→ }, 92→]; 93→ 94→const COMPARISON = { 95→ overlap: [ 96→ "Both agree: AI capability acceleration is real and accelerating", 97→ "Both agree: current institutions are not prepared for the speed of change", 98→ "Both agree: the economic consequences will be severe for some cohorts", 99→ "Both agree: the geopolitical dimension is underappreciated", 100→ "Both agree: traditional policy tools may be insufficient", 101→ ], 102→ divergence: [ 103→ { topic: "Focus", citrini: "Economic consequences + financial contagion", leopold: "Capability trajectory + geopolitics + security" }, 104→ { topic: "Timeline", citrini: "Crisis by 2027-2028", leopold: "AGI by 2027, superintelligence shortly after" }, 105→ { topic: "Mechanism", citrini: "Displacement → consumption collapse → financial contagion", leopold: "Capability → intelligence explosion → geopolitical race" }, 106→ { topic: "Who loses?", citrini: "White-collar workers, SaaS companies, PE-backed software, eventually everyone", leopold: "Whoever loses the AGI race (nations, not individuals)" }, 107→ { topic: "Policy", citrini: "Government too slow to respond to displacement", leopold: "Government must nationalize and control AGI development" }, 108→ { topic: "Investable?", citrini: "Yes — specific trades (long vol, short SaaS, long infrastructure)", leopold: "Yes — his $1.5B fund is the trade" }, 109→ ], 110→ synthesis: "Leopold tells you WHAT is being built. Citrini tells you WHO gets hurt when it arrives. The Boom rebuttal tells you who ADAPTS. Your strategy needs to account for all three: position for the capability buildout (AI infrastructure), hedge against the displacement (hard assets), and BUILD the adaptation (Lucid Box — you ARE the 'New Guilds' thesis in action).", 111→}; 112→ 113→export default function SourceMaterials() { 114→ const [expanded, setExpanded] = useState(0); 115→ const [showComparison, setShowComparison] = useState(false); 116→ 117→ return ( 118→

content.thinking:
The user is asking if the HTML playground route would lose capabilities. Let me think about this:

The JSX components use:
- `useState` from React — works fine with CDN React
- Inline styles — no CSS modules or Tailwind needed
- No routing — just two views, could be tab-switched
- No external dependencies beyond React
- No API calls, no backend
- No file I/O, no persistence (beyond what's in the data arrays)

The only thing you'd "lose" with HTML vs Vite:
1. Hot module reload during development (minor)
2. Proper routing/URL paths (could use hash routing or tabs)


3. Module bundling and TypeScript support (neither are needed here)
4. Streamlined deployment to hosting platforms (though HTML can still be deployed)

For this project, nothing functionally important is lost — it's self-contained with no external data fetching or complex state management. But since they're treating it as a standalone project in their Projects folder, a proper structure would give them more flexibility if they want to add features like data persistence or real signal updates later.

I should be straightforward about the tradeoffs rather than overselling either approach.

content.text:
No, you wouldn't lose anything meaningful for what these components do. Here's why:

**What these components use:**
- React `useState` — works fine via CDN
- Inline styles only — no build step needed
- No API calls, no backend, no external deps
- Pure data display + interactive expand/collapse

**What HTML gives you:**
- Zero setup — double-click and it opens
- Both views as tabs in one file
- Fully functional, all interactivity preserved

**What you'd gain with Vite (that you don't need yet):**
- Hot reload during dev (nice but minor for a dashboard)
- URL routing between pages (tabs work fine)
- Easier to add API calls later (e.g., live signal data)
- Deploy to Vercel with a push

My recommendation: **start with HTML playground** in `~/Projects/AsymmetricBridge`. If you later want live data feeds or deployment, I can convert it to a Vite project in minutes. You lose nothing and ship faster.

This pushes us toward a Vite React project. Let me think about what data sources map to the signals in the tracker:

**Live data possibilities:**
- Stock prices (BX, APO, KKR, SNOW, NOW, CRM, ZS) → CoinCap MCP for crypto, financial APIs for stocks


- Crypto/stablecoin volume and economic indicators like JOLTS, BLS, GDP, and M2 velocity can come from CoinCap MCP and free APIs like FRED and BLS

content.text:
That changes things — Vite React it is. Live data feeds need proper API integration.

Let me think through what's feasible for the signals in your tracker:

**Easy to get live:**
- Stock prices (BX, APO, KKR, SNOW, NOW, CRM, ZS) — free financial APIs
- Crypto/stablecoin volumes — CoinCap MCP you already have
- FRED economic data (M2 velocity, labor share, GDP, deficit) — free API, no key needed
- Treasury yields — FRED

**Harder / manual:**
- JOLTS, BLS employment breakdowns — FRED has these but they're monthly/quarterly
- Challenger layoff data — paywalled
- YC batch analysis — manual/Claude Code
- Congressional activity — manual/Claude Code

**The hybrid model makes sense:**
- Live API feeds auto-update what they can (prices, FRED macro data, crypto)
- Claude Code sessions update qualitative signals (assessments, status changes, notes)
- Signal statuses (green/amber/red) get persisted locally so they survive reloads

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/fabianaguilar/Projects/ALOS/.claude/skills/scaffold-project

# /scaffold-project — New Project with ALOS Integration

Create a new project from scratch with the full ALOS toolchain wired up. This is Phase 0 — before even `/clarify`.

## Usage

```bash
/scaffold-project                    # Start interview
/scaffold-project [name] [type]      # Quick scaffold (skip interview)
```

## Pipeline Position

```
★ /scaffold-project ★ → /clarify → /spec → /design → /forge → ...
```

---

## Phase 1: Interview (4 questions max)

Keep it fast. This is project setup, not project planning.

**Q1: Project name?**
- Will become directory name and repo name
- Suggest kebab-case: `my-cool-app`
- Validate: no spaces, no special chars, not already taken in `~/Projects/`

**Q2: What kind of project?**

Present TWO categories. The choice determines the entire scaffold pipeline.

**Coding Projects** (full pipeline: docs/ 4+1 Diataxis, playground, dev tooling):

| Type | Stack Default |
|------|--------------|
| Web app | Next.js + TypeScript |
| Mobile app | React Native / Expo |
| CLI tool | Node (TypeScript) or Python |
| API / Backend | Node (Express/Fastify) or Python (FastAPI) |
| Library / Package | TypeScript or Python |

**Non-Coding Projects** (lighter scaffold: docs/ 4 Diataxis categories, no playground, no dev pipeline steps):

| Type | Stack Default |
|------|--------------|
| Static site / Landing page | HTML + Tailwind |
| Content project | Obsidian / Markdown |
| Writing project | Markdown |

Internally track `project_category` as `coding` or `non-coding` — this gates Phase 4 and changes templates.

**Q3: Tech stack preferences?**
- "Use your judgment" → auto-select based on type
- Or specify: "Use Svelte instead of React", "Python not Node", etc.

**Q4: Playground type?** (Coding projects ONLY — skip for non-coding)

Present a suggestion based on project type, then let the user choose:

| Project Type | Suggested Playground |
|-------------|---------------------|
| Web app | Content/Config Editor |
| Mobile app | Component Configurator |
| CLI tool | Command Builder |
| API / Backend | Endpoint Explorer |
| Library / Package | API Playground |

Options: accept suggestion, customize (describe what you want), or skip.

---

## Phase 2: Scaffold Directory Structure

Create at `~/Projects/[project-name]/`.

### Always Create (Every Project)

```
[project-name]/
├── CLAUDE.md                  # Project instructions (lean template)
├── .claude/
│   └── context/               # On-demand context files
├── QUESTIONS.md               # Architecture & design questions
├── productivity/
│   ├── TODO.md                # Task tracking (pipeline-aware)
│   └── SESSION_LOG.md         # Session history
├── docs/
│   ├── INDEX.md               # Diataxis context router table
│   └── tutorials/
│       └── getting-started.md # Setup guide with real content
└── .gitignore                 # Appropriate for tech stack
```

### For Coding Projects, Also Create

```
├── docs/
│   └── reference/
│       └── decisions/
│           └── TEMPLATE.md    # ADR template
```

**NO empty folders.** `docs/how-to/` and `docs/explanation/` get created by later pipeline steps (`/wrap-up`, `/design`). Do not pre-create them.

### For Multi-Agent Projects (Most Projects)

```
├── AGENTS.md                  # Codex context file
└── GEMINI.md                  # Gemini context file
```

Ask: "Will you use Codex or Gemini for this project?" Default: yes → create both.

### CLAUDE.md Template

## Identity
**Type:** [web app / CLI / API / etc.]

---

## Phase 3: Scaffold Docs (Diataxis Context Router)

Generate the documentation files with REAL content — not empty stubs.

### docs/INDEX.md — Context Router Table

Generate this file using the project name, type, and category:

```markdown
# Documentation Index — [Project Name]

> This is the documentation map. Each entry links to a specific doc and notes which pipeline step creates it.

## Quick Navigation

| I need to... | Go to | Created by |
|-------------|-------|-----------|
| Get the project running | [Getting Started](tutorials/getting-started.md) | `/scaffold-project` |
| Understand architecture decisions | [ADR Log](reference/decisions/) | `/design` |
| Learn why we chose this approach | [Design Rationale](explanation/design-rationale.md) | `/design` |
| Configure or customize | [How-To Guides](how-to/) | `/wrap-up` (as patterns emerge) |
| Try it interactively | [Playground](playgrounds/) | `/scaffold-project` |

## Diataxis Categories

| Category | Purpose | Status |
|----------|---------|--------|
| tutorials/ | Learning-oriented (step-by-step) | getting-started.md |
| how-to/ | Task-oriented (solve a problem) | Created as patterns emerge |
| reference/ | Information-oriented (accurate, complete) | decisions/TEMPLATE.md |
| explanation/ | Understanding-oriented (the "why") | Created by /design |
| playgrounds/ | Interaction-oriented (configure visually) | [Coding only] |
```

For non-coding projects, remove the `playgrounds/` row and the "Try it interactively" row from Quick Navigation. Also remove the `reference/decisions/` row from Quick Navigation if not a coding project.

### docs/tutorials/getting-started.md — Real Content from Tech Stack

Generate this with actual commands based on the chosen tech stack:

\`\`\`
Run `/pipeline status` to see where you are.

## Next Steps

- [ ] Run `/spec` to decompose into features and tasks
```

Use the ACTUAL tech stack to fill in prerequisites and commands. Examples:

|-------|--------------|---------|-----|
| Next.js + TS | Node 20+, npm | `npm install` | `npm run dev` |
| React Native / Expo | Node 20+, Expo CLI | `npm install` | `npx expo start` |
| Python + uv | Python 3.12+, uv | `uv sync` | `uv run main.py` |
| FastAPI | Python 3.12+, uv | `uv sync` | `uv run uvicorn main:app --reload` |
| HTML + Tailwind | Browser | N/A | Open `index.html` |
| Markdown | Obsidian or text editor | N/A | Open in Obsidian |

### docs/reference/decisions/TEMPLATE.md (Coding Projects Only)

```markdown
# ADR-[NNN]: [Decision Title]

**Status:** [Proposed | Accepted | Deprecated | Superseded]
**Date:** [YYYY-MM-DD]
**Deciders:** [Names]

## Context
[What is the issue that we're seeing that is motivating this decision?]

## Decision
[What is the change that we're proposing and/or doing?]

## Consequences
### Positive
- [What becomes easier?]

### Negative
- [What becomes harder?]

### Neutral
- [What other changes does this require?]
```

---

## Phase 4: Scaffold Playground (Coding Projects Only)

**Skip this phase entirely for non-coding projects or if user chose "skip" in Q4.**

Based on the Q4 interview answer, generate a functional HTML playground:

### Playground Requirements

- **3-panel layout:** sidebar controls (340px) + preview (flex-1) + output area
- **localStorage persistence:** All user inputs survive page reload
- **Obsidian export:** Button to copy formatted markdown to clipboard for Kosha Prime
- **Tooltips:** On all non-obvious controls and sections
- **Dark theme:** Dark background, high-contrast text
- **Copy-to-clipboard:** On all output sections
- **Functional from day one:** Not a wireframe — buttons work, state persists, exports run

### Playground Types by Project

| Playground Type | What It Does |
|----------------|--------------|
| Content/Config Editor | Edit project config values, preview rendered output |
| Component Configurator | Toggle props/variants, see live component preview |
| Command Builder | Build CLI commands with flags, copy to clipboard |
| Endpoint Explorer | Compose API requests, view mock responses |
| API Playground | Call library functions with params, see return values |

### File Location

Place at `docs/playgrounds/[playground-name].html`

The playground should be a STARTER — functional but minimal. It gives the project an interactive exploration tool from day one. Use the Task tool to spawn playground generation if needed for complexity.

### Canonical Pattern Reference

Follow the playground patterns from ALOS memory:
- Single HTML file, self-contained (inline CSS + JS)
- CSS custom properties for theming
- Modular JS with clear init/render/export functions
- localStorage keys namespaced to the project: `[project-name]-playground-*`

---

## Phase 5: Initialize Git + GitHub

```bash
cd ~/Projects/[project-name]
git init
git add .
git commit -m "chore: scaffold project with ALOS integration"
gh repo create [project-name] --private --source=. --push
```

**Always private** unless user explicitly says otherwise.

If `gh` is not authenticated or fails, skip GitHub creation and note: "Run `gh auth login` to set up GitHub, then `gh repo create`."

---

## Phase 6: Register in Kosha Prime

Create project brief at:
`Kosha Prime/Projects/Current/[ProjectName]/brief.md`

```markdown
---
created: [date]
status: active
type: [project type]
category: [coding | non-coding]
stack: [tech stack]
---

# [Project Name]

## Vision
[To be filled after /clarify]

## Status
Scaffolded. Next: /clarify or /spec

## Links
- Repo: github.com/[user]/[project-name]
- Local: ~/Projects/[project-name]
```

---

## Phase 7: Tech Stack Setup (Optional)

If user chose a known stack, offer to scaffold:

| Type | Command | What It Does |
|------|---------|--------------|
| Next.js | `npx create-next-app@latest . --typescript --tailwind --app --src-dir` | Full Next.js setup |
| Expo | `npx create-expo-app .` | React Native with Expo |
| Python | `uv init` | Python project with uv |
| Node CLI | Manual `package.json` + `bin` + `tsconfig` | TypeScript CLI setup |

Ask before running: "Want me to set up the [stack] boilerplate too, or just the ALOS structure?"

If boilerplate is created, amend the initial commit to include it.

---

## Output

```markdown
## Project Scaffolded: [name]

**Type:** [project type] ([coding/non-coding])
**Stack:** [tech stack]
**Location:** ~/Projects/[name]
**GitHub:** github.com/[user]/[name]

### Files Created
- CLAUDE.md — project instructions (with docs/ import)
- docs/INDEX.md — documentation context router
- docs/tutorials/getting-started.md — setup guide
- [if coding] docs/reference/decisions/TEMPLATE.md — ADR template
- [if coding] docs/playgrounds/[name].html — interactive playground
- AGENTS.md — Codex context
- GEMINI.md — Gemini context
- QUESTIONS.md — question capture
- productivity/TODO.md — pipeline-aware task tracking
- productivity/SESSION_LOG.md — session history
- .gitignore

### Registered
- Kosha Prime brief: Projects/Current/[Name]/brief.md

### Next Step
[Coding] Run `/clarify` to sharpen your vision, then `/spec` to decompose into features.
[Non-coding] Run `/clarify` to define scope, then start creating content.
```

---

## Integration

| From | Trigger | Action |
|------|---------|--------|
| `/pipeline new` | No project directory | Route to `/scaffold-project` |
| `/clarify` | "This looks like a new project" | Suggest `/scaffold-project` first |
| After scaffold | Project created | Suggest `/clarify` → `/spec` |
| Phase 3 | Docs scaffolded | INDEX.md imported into CLAUDE.md via `@docs/INDEX.md` |
| Phase 4 | Playground generated | Linked from INDEX.md, placed in docs/playgrounds/ |

## Constraints

- **Never overwrite** — if project directory exists, warn and ask before proceeding
- **Private repos by default** — always `--private` unless explicitly told otherwise
- **Lean CLAUDE.md** — use the universal template, not a massive file
- **Register in Kosha Prime** — every project gets a brief, no exceptions
- **Don't force tech stack** — offer boilerplate, don't assume
- **No empty folders** — only create directories that contain at least one file
- **Category gates matter** — non-coding projects skip Phase 4 and get simpler templates
- **Playgrounds must work** — if generated, they must be functional (persistence, export, tooltips)

# Asymmetric Bridge — Codex Context

## What This Project Does
Personal strategic intelligence dashboard with two main sections:
1. **Lucid Box Business** — Product ladder, ALOS productization, Twitter/X strategy, revenue projections, content calendar for AI consulting business
2. **Signal Tracker** — 6-domino cascade model tracking macro indicators for an "Intelligence Crisis" thesis (SaaS compression, white-collar displacement, friction collapse, Ghost GDP, financial contagion, policy response)

Live data feeds (FRED, stock prices, crypto) auto-update quantitative signals. Claude Code sessions update qualitative assessments and signal statuses.

## Tech Stack
- Vite + React (no TypeScript)
- Supabase (persistence: signal statuses, data points, assessments, live data cache)
- FRED API (economic indicators: M2, labor share, GDP, JOLTS, yields)
- CoinGecko API (crypto prices, stablecoin volumes)
- Financial data API (stock prices: BX, APO, KKR, SNOW, NOW, CRM, ZS)
- IBM Plex Sans/Mono fonts, dark theme (#0D0D0F)

## Key Files
- src/components/CommandCenter.jsx — main dashboard
- src/components/SourceMaterials.jsx — thesis comparison page
- src/data/ — static data (dominos, products, sources, twitter pillars, revenue)
- src/lib/ — API clients (supabase, fred, stocks, crypto)
- src/hooks/ — data fetching hooks

## Current Tasks
[To be filled from TODO.md]

## Conventions
- Inline styles (project convention from source components)
- Data/logic separation: static data in src/data/, live in src/lib/
- Supabase for ALL persistence
- Free-tier APIs only

# Getting Started with Asymmetric Bridge

## Prerequisites
- Node 20+
- npm
- Supabase account (free tier)
- FRED API key (free — https://fred.stlouisfed.org/docs/api/api_key.html)

## Quick Start
```bash
git clone git@github.com:yourusername/AsymmetricBridge.git
cd AsymmetricBridge
npm install
cp .env.example .env    # Fill in API keys
npm run dev
```

## Environment Variables
```
VITE_SUPABASE_URL=your-supabase-url
VITE_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY=your-anon-key
VITE_FRED_API_KEY=your-fred-key
```

## Project Structure
```
AsymmetricBridge/
├── CLAUDE.md                  # Project instructions
├── AGENTS.md                  # Codex context
├── GEMINI.md                  # Gemini context
├── QUESTIONS.md               # Architecture questions
├── productivity/
│   ├── TODO.md                # Task tracking
│   └── SESSION_LOG.md         # Session history
├── docs/
│   ├── INDEX.md               # Documentation map
│   ├── tutorials/
│   │   └── getting-started.md # This file
│   └── reference/
│       └── decisions/
│           └── TEMPLATE.md    # ADR template
├── src/
│   ├── main.jsx               # Entry point
│   ├── App.jsx                # Root component + routing
│   ├── components/            # UI components
│   │   ├── CommandCenter.jsx  # Main dashboard
│   │   └── SourceMaterials.jsx # Thesis comparison
│   ├── data/                  # Static data
│   ├── lib/                   # API clients
│   └── hooks/                 # Data fetching hooks
└── supabase/
    └── migrations/            # Database schema
```

## Development Pipeline
This project uses the ALOS development pipeline:
```
/scaffold-project → /clarify → /spec → /design → /forge → /self-review → /ship
```
Run `/pipeline status` to see where you are.

## Next Steps
- [ ] Run `/clarify` to sharpen the project vision
- [ ] Run `/spec` to decompose into features and tasks

```

## Development Pipeline
This project uses the ALOS development pipeline:
```
/scaffold-project → /clarify → /spec → /design → /forge → /self-review → /ship
```
Run `/pipeline status` to see where you are.

- [ ] Run `/clarify` to sharpen the project vision
- [ ] Run `/spec` to decompose into features and tasks

Base directory for this skill: /Users/fabianaguilar/.claude/skills/clarify

# Clarify — Pre-Prompt Clarity Engineering

Force the cognitive work that separates great outputs from slop. This skill runs the "invisible work" that should happen before any major creative prompt.

## Philosophy

From the article: "The gap between what you want and what you get has nothing to do with the model being limited... it's about you not knowing what you want with enough precision to communicate it."

This skill forces precision BEFORE typing the actual prompt.

## Recommended Output Style

> 💡 Clarity engineering pairs well with **Strategist** mode: `/mode strat`

## When to Use

- Before writing any significant creative content
- Before designing a new feature or system
- Before generating anything that "could go either way"
- When you have a vague idea that needs sharpening
- When you've been getting generic outputs and can't figure out why

## Usage

```
/clarify                    # Start clarity interview
/clarify "product launch"   # Start with context
```

## The Clarity Interview

Ask these questions ONE AT A TIME. Wait for each answer before proceeding.

### Phase 1: What Are We Making?

**Q1: The One-Liner**
"In one sentence, what are we creating?"

*Listen for: vagueness, "something like", "kind of"*
*If vague, push back: "That's the problem. Let's get specific. What EXACTLY?"*

### Phase 2: The Differentiation Questions

**Q2: The Slop Test**
"Picture the generic, boring, AI-slop version of this. What would make someone scroll past it? Now—what will make YOUR version different?"

*This is the most important question. Push for specifics.*

**Q3: The Emotion Map**
"What emotion do you want to create? At what exact moment? Walk me through the journey."

*For non-emotional outputs (code, analysis), rephrase: "What 'aha moment' should the reader have? Where in the output?"*

**Q4: The Success Snapshot**
"Imagine it's done perfectly. Describe what you're looking at. Be specific about format, length, style."

### Phase 3: Reference Hunting

**Q5: The Reference**
"Is there an example that makes you say 'yes, exactly like this'? It doesn't have to be the same domain—just captures the vibe, structure, or quality level."

*If they have one: Offer to analyze it together*
*If not: Offer to search for references together using WebSearch*

**Q6: The Anti-Reference**
"What's an example of what you DON'T want? What would make this fail?"

### Phase 4: Constraints & Scope

**Q7: The Boundaries**
"What's explicitly OUT of scope? What should we NOT include, even if it seems related?"

**Q8: The Audience**
"Who is this for? Not 'everyone'—who specifically? What do they already know? What are they skeptical about?"

## Output: Clarity Document

After the interview, generate a structured document:

```markdown
# Clarity Brief: {Project/Output Name}
Generated: {date}

## The Vision
{One clear sentence from Q1, refined}

## What Makes This Different
{From Q2 - the anti-slop differentiation}

## Emotional/Experience Journey
{From Q3 - the feeling/aha moments mapped}

## Success Looks Like
{From Q4 - concrete description of the output}

## Reference Anchor
{From Q5 - the "exactly like this" example}
- What to borrow: {specific elements}
- What to avoid: {from Q6}

## Boundaries
**In Scope:** {list}
**Out of Scope:** {list}

## Audience Profile
- Who: {specific person}
- Already knows: {list}
- Skeptical about: {list}

## Ready-to-Use Context Block

Use this at the start of prompts for this project:

---
I'm creating {one-liner}.

What makes this different from generic output: {differentiation}.

The key moment I'm engineering for: {emotion/aha moment}.

Success looks like: {snapshot}.

Reference style: {reference} — specifically borrowing {elements}.

Avoid: {anti-reference elements}.

Audience: {profile} who already knows {X} but is skeptical about {Y}.

Not in scope: {boundaries}.
---
```

## Persist the Brief

After generating the clarity document, **always write it to disk**:

**Output location:** `$PROJECT_ROOT/CLARITY-BRIEF.md` (if inside a project directory)
**Fallback:** Write inline and offer `/save-prompt` to save to prompt library.

This file is read by `/spec` and `/design` as upstream context. If it doesn't exist on disk, the clarity work is lost between sessions.

## Integration with Other Skills

### With /scaffold-project
If clarifying for a new project, offer:
"This looks like a new project. Want to run /scaffold-project with this clarity context?"

### With /spec
After clarity brief is saved, suggest:
"Ready to decompose into features? Run `/spec` — it will read your CLARITY-BRIEF.md automatically."

### With /save-prompt
After generating clarity document, offer:
"Save this clarity brief to your prompt library for reuse?"

### With /prompt-library
Can load existing clarity briefs as starting context.

## Behavioral Notes

- **Push back on vagueness.** If answers are generic, say "That's too vague. Give me something specific."
- **Reference hunting is optional but powerful.** If they don't have one, help find one.
- **The output is a tool, not a deliverable.** The clarity document is meant to be USED, not filed.
- **This is uncomfortable by design.** The questions should force thinking that normally gets skipped.

## Quick Mode

If user says `/clarify quick`, compress to three questions:
1. What exactly are we making?
2. What makes this different from the generic version?
3. What does success look like?

Generate abbreviated clarity block.

---

#prompting #clarity #pre-work #cognitive-architecture


ARGUMENTS: How live data maps to signal statuses (auto-threshold vs. manual assessment?)
  - Refresh cadence strategy (real-time vs. daily vs. on-demand)
  - Claude Code integration pattern (CLI commands? dedicated skill?)  Explain these options and give me more possible things to clarify that you may need

Good — you've already identified three architectural questions. Let me sharpen those and surface the ones you haven't thought of yet.

Let me start with the clarity interview, but I'll adapt it since you already have a built product vision (the JSX components exist). This is about engineering precision on the *live data layer* and *interaction model* — the parts that don't exist yet.

---

**Q1: The One-Liner**

From what I see, this is: *"A personal strategic intelligence dashboard that merges live macro data with manual thesis tracking to inform both investment positioning and Lucid Box business timing."*

Is that right, or is the emphasis different? Is this primarily a **decision-making tool** (you check it before making moves), a **monitoring tool** (it alerts you when signals change), or a **presentation tool** (you show it to clients/audience to build credibility)?

options.description: Decision tool, monitor, and public-facing asset. Full weight on all three.

content.thinking:
That changes things significantly. This isn't just a personal tool — it's a product that people can fork/clone and customize with their own data. That means:

1. The Lucid Box business data needs to be configurable/replaceable (not hardcoded to Fabian's specific products)
2. The signal tracker framework is universal (macro data) but the personal positioning layer is customizable
3. The architecture needs to separate "framework" from "personal data"
4. This ties directly into the Lucid Box content strategy — open source tool → credibility → audience → customers

This is actually a much more interesting product. Let me continue the clarity interview to nail down the specifics.

content.text:
That makes complete sense — and it changes the architecture significantly. This isn't just a personal dashboard anymore. It's a **framework** that ships with your thesis as the default, but anyone can plug in their own:

- Career/business data (instead of Lucid Box products)
- Personal positioning strategy (instead of your Twitter pillars)
- Revenue model (their own income streams)
- Signal tracker stays universal (macro data affects everyone)

That means the architecture needs a clean separation: **framework** (signal tracker, data feeds, UI) vs. **personal config** (business products, career plan, positioning).

This is the Lucid Box flywheel in action — open source tool → credibility → audience → customers.

---

**Q2: The Slop Test**

The generic version of this would be "another finance dashboard with charts." What's different is the **domino cascade model** — the thesis that these signals are connected in sequence, not independent. And the personal positioning layer — "here's what the macro means for YOUR career."

Let me now work through the architectural decisions you raised, plus the ones this open-source angle surfaces.

questions.question: How should live data map to signal statuses? This determines how much human judgment stays in the loop.

options.label: Auto-threshold + manual override
options.description: Live data auto-flips green/amber/red when it crosses defined thresholds (e.g., NRR < 110% = amber). You can override any status manually via Claude Code. Best of both worlds.

options.label: Manual only, data-informed
options.description: Live data shows current values but YOU decide when to flip statuses. Claude Code suggests changes, you approve. Maximum human judgment.

options.label: Fully automatic
options.description: Thresholds are pre-defined, live data auto-updates everything. Minimal human input. Risk: false signals from noisy data.

questions.question: How often should live data refresh?

options.label: Smart cadence (Recommended)
options.description: Stock prices: every 15min during market hours. FRED macro: daily (data updates monthly/quarterly anyway). Crypto: every 5min. Manual signals: on-demand via Claude Code.

options.label: On-demand only
options.description: Data refreshes when you open the dashboard or click refresh. Saves API calls, but you might miss moves.

options.label: Real-time where possible
options.description: WebSocket for stocks/crypto, polling for FRED. Most responsive but highest API cost and complexity.

questions.question: How should Claude Code integrate for manual updates?

options.label: Dedicated /signal-update skill
options.description: New ALOS skill: '/signal-update domino:2 signal:JOLTS status:red notes:collapsed below 1.5M'. Writes directly to Supabase. Fast, scriptable.

options.label: Direct Supabase edits
options.description: Claude Code reads/writes signal_statuses table directly via SQL or API. No skill needed, just natural conversation: 'update JOLTS to red'.

options.label: Both
options.description: Skill for quick updates, direct Supabase for complex analysis sessions. Skill calls the same API under the hood.

questions.question: For the open-source angle: how configurable should v1 be?

options.label: Config file approach
options.description: Single config.json defines personal data (products, career, revenue). Signal framework is universal. Users edit one file to customize.

options.label: Onboarding wizard
options.description: First-run setup flow asks users about their career, products, income streams. Generates their personal config. More polished but more work.

options.label: Ship personal first, abstract later
options.description: v1 is YOUR dashboard with hardcoded Lucid Box data. v2 extracts the config layer for open source. Ship fast, generalize second.

# Clarity Brief: Asymmetric Bridge
Generated: 2026-02-22

## The Vision
A personal strategic intelligence dashboard that merges live macro data feeds with manual thesis tracking to inform investment positioning, Lucid Box business timing, and career decisions — built as a "supreme" personal instance first, then extracted as an open-source framework for others to customize.

## What Makes This Different
Not another finance dashboard with charts. The differentiator is the **domino cascade model** — the thesis that macro signals are connected in sequence (SaaS compression → white-collar displacement → friction collapse → Ghost GDP → financial contagion → policy response), not independent. Combined with a **personal positioning layer** that maps what the macro means for YOUR specific career, business, and investments.

## Emotional/Experience Journey
1. **Open the dashboard** → immediate clarity on where things stand (threat level, signal counts)
2. **Drill into dominos** → understand exactly which signals are moving and why
3. **Check Lucid Box** → see how macro context maps to business timing decisions
4. **Receive a Telegram alert** → a signal crossed a threshold, time to pay attention
5. **Run Claude Code analysis** → update qualitative assessments with reasoning, history tracks the change

The "aha moment": seeing the cascade in real-time — when Domino 1 flips amber and you can trace the chain forward to anticipate what's next.

## Success Looks Like
- Dashboard loads with live data (stock prices, FRED macro, crypto) already populated
- Signal statuses auto-update when thresholds are crossed, with manual override capability
- Every status change is timestamped and visible in history
- Lucid Box business section shows product ladder, revenue projections, content calendar
- Source materials section with thesis comparison is accessible
- Telegram notifications fire when signals cross thresholds
- Claude Code can update any signal status, add data points, write assessments via dedicated skill + direct Supabase
- Deployed on Vercel, accessible from any device
- Desktop-first design, doesn't break on mobile

## Two-Track Strategy
1. **Personal "Supreme" Instance** (v1, now): Hardcoded Lucid Box data, full ALOS context, all signal assessments pre-loaded, Claude Code integration. This is the operational tool.
2. **Open Source Framework** (v2, later): Onboarding wizard replaces hardcoded personal data. Users plug in their own career, business, income streams. Signal tracker stays universal. This is the Lucid Box content/product play.

## Reference Anchor
- The existing JSX components (command-center.jsx, source-materials.jsx) define the visual language: dark theme (#0D0D0F), IBM Plex Sans/Mono, color-coded dominos, expandable cards
- **Borrow:** The UI patterns, color system, data structure, information hierarchy
- **Avoid:** Static-only data, no persistence, no live feeds, no alerting

## Boundaries
**In Scope (v1):**
- Full Command Center (products, ALOS productization, Twitter/X, revenue, content)
- Full Signal Tracker (6 dominos, 24 signals, live data feeds)
- Source Materials (4 sources, comparison/synthesis)
- Supabase persistence (signal statuses, data points, assessments, history)
- Live data: FRED API, stock prices, CoinGecko crypto
- Auto-threshold with manual override
- Smart cadence (stocks 15min, FRED daily, crypto 5min)
- Telegram alerts on threshold breaches (email fallback)
- Signal history tracking (all changes timestamped)
- Claude Code integration (dedicated skill + direct Supabase)
- Vercel deployment
- Desktop-first, responsive but not mobile-optimized

**Out of Scope (v1):**
- Open-source extraction / onboarding wizard (v2)
- User authentication (personal instance, no multi-user)
- Real-time WebSocket connections (smart polling is sufficient)
- News sentiment analysis (future enhancement)
- Job posting trend APIs (BLS/FRED proxies for now)
- Mobile-native app
- Public-facing marketing page

## Audience Profile (v1)
- **Who:** Fabian — sole user of the personal instance
- **Already knows:** The thesis cold (Citrini, Leopold, Bull Rebuttal), all Lucid Box products, ALOS architecture
- **Needs:** Fast signal-checking, data-driven threshold alerts, historical tracking of how signals evolve

## Audience Profile (v2 — Open Source)
- **Who:** Knowledge workers, solopreneurs, indie builders who are paying attention to AI disruption
- **Already knows:** AI is changing the economy, probably read at least one of the source articles
- **Skeptical about:** Whether a dashboard actually helps them prepare, vs. just being "doom scrolling with graphs"

## Architecture Decisions

### Data Layer
- **Supabase tables:** signal_statuses, signal_data_points, signal_history, live_data_cache, assessments
- **Auto-threshold logic:** Runs client-side — compares live data against threshold definitions, auto-flips status
- **Manual override:** Claude Code writes directly to signal_statuses with override flag, preserving auto-threshold alongside

### API Strategy (Free Tier)
- **FRED:** Free API key, 120 requests/min. Covers: M2 velocity, labor share, GDP, JOLTS, consumer confidence, federal receipts, deficit
- **Stock prices:** Financial data API (Alpha Vantage free: 25/day, or Twelve Data free: 800/day)
- **CoinGecko:** Free tier, no key for basic. Covers: crypto prices, stablecoin market cap
- **Telegram Bot API:** Free, unlimited messages to self

### Refresh Cadence
| Source | Frequency | Reason |
|--------|-----------|--------|
| Stock prices | 15min during market hours | Balance freshness vs. rate limits |
| Crypto | 5min | Markets 24/7, volatile |
| FRED macro | Daily check | Underlying data updates monthly/quarterly |
| Manual signals | On-demand via Claude Code | Human judgment, no schedule |

### Claude Code Integration
- **Skill:** `/signal-update` — quick CLI-style updates (status, notes, data points)
- **Direct Supabase:** For complex analysis sessions, Claude Code reads/writes tables naturally
- **Both share same Supabase API** — skill is a convenience wrapper

### Alerting
- **Primary:** Telegram Bot → personal chat
- **Fallback:** Email via Supabase Edge Function + Resend
- **Trigger:** Any signal status change (green→amber, amber→red, or manual override)

## Ready-to-Use Context Block

---
I'm building Asymmetric Bridge — a personal strategic intelligence dashboard that merges live macro data with thesis tracking.

What makes this different: the domino cascade model (signals are connected in sequence, not independent) plus a personal business positioning layer.

The key moment: seeing a signal cross a threshold and tracing the cascade forward.

Success: live data auto-updating, threshold alerts via Telegram, full history of signal changes, Claude Code integration for qualitative analysis.

Architecture: Vite + React + Supabase + FRED + CoinGecko + financial data APIs. Deployed on Vercel. Desktop-first.

Two-track: personal "supreme" instance now, open-source framework later.

Not in scope for v1: multi-user auth, onboarding wizard, mobile app, news sentiment.
---

content.text:
Clarity brief written to `CLARITY-BRIEF.md`. Here's the summary of what we locked in:

**Architecture Decisions:**
- Auto-threshold + manual override for signal statuses
- Smart cadence (stocks 15min, FRED daily, crypto 5min)
- `/signal-update` skill + direct Supabase for Claude Code
- Telegram alerts (primary), email (fallback)
- Full signal history tracking
- Vercel deployment, desktop-first

**Two-Track Strategy:**
- v1: Your "supreme" personal instance with all ALOS context baked in
- v2: Open-source framework with onboarding wizard for others

**Scope locked:** Full Command Center + Signal Tracker + Sources, all with live data and Supabase persistence.

**Next step:** `/spec` to decompose this into implementable features and tasks. The clarity brief feeds directly into spec decomposition. Want to run it?

Base directory for this skill: /Users/fabianaguilar/Projects/ALOS/.claude/skills/spec

# /spec — Product Spec → Tasks → Ship

Capture what you're building, break it into tasks an AI agent can one-shot, and scale to parallel worktrees when the project is big.

## Usage

```bash
/spec                     # Start spec interview for current project
/spec from <file>         # Parse existing spec/PRD document
/spec tasks               # Show current task decomposition
/spec status              # Check implementation progress
```

## The Pipeline

```
SPEC → FEATURES → TASKS → (worktrees if big) → SHIP
```

---

## Phase 0: Load Upstream Context

Before starting the interview, check for existing artifacts:

1. **`CLARITY-BRIEF.md`** — If it exists, read it. Pre-fill answers from the clarity brief instead of re-asking. Show the user what was imported: "I loaded your clarity brief. Here's what I already know: [summary]. Let me fill in the gaps."
2. **`SPEC.md`** — If it exists, switch to update mode (see "Updating a Spec" below).

---

## Phase 1: Capture the Spec

### Option A: Interview Mode (default)

Ask these 5 questions. Keep answers tight — this is a 5-minute exercise, not a planning retreat.

**1. What does it do?**
> 2-3 sentences. If you can't explain it in 3 sentences, you don't know what you're building yet.

**2. Who is it for?**
> One user type + their use case. "Teachers who need to generate lesson plans from standards."

**3. Core features?**
> List 3-8 features. Each one line. If it's more than 8, you're building two products.

**4. Constraints?**
> Platform, cost ceiling, dependencies, timeline, tech stack. What CAN'T you do?

**5. Done when?**
> 3 concrete acceptance criteria. How do you know it's finished? "A user can X, Y, and Z."

### Option B: Parse Existing Spec

If the user provides a file (`/spec from SPEC.md` or `/spec from prd.txt`):

1. Read the document
2. Extract the 5 sections above from whatever format they wrote
3. Present back for confirmation: "Here's what I extracted — correct?"
4. If missing sections, ask only for what's missing

### AI Project Check

**If the project involves AI interactions** (LLM calls, model inference, AI-generated content):

Surface the AI Interaction Atlas framework. Ask:
- What AI tasks? (classify, generate, verify, etc.)
- What human tasks? (review, approve, edit?)
- What constraints? (latency, cost, safety, oversight level?)

Reference: `Kosha Prime/Reference/AI-Interaction-Atlas.md`

**If the project is React/RN with AI-generated UI for end users:**

Surface json-render as a tool option.
Reference: `Kosha Prime/Reference/JSON-Render-Generative-UI.md`

---

## Phase 2: Decompose into Features

Take each core feature from the spec and define:

```markdown
### Feature: [Name]

**What:** [One sentence]
**Depends on:** [Other features, or "None"]
**Files:** [Expected files/directories this touches]
**Acceptance:** [How to verify it works]
```

Order features by dependency — what must exist before what?

Output a dependency graph:

```
Feature A (no deps)
Feature B (no deps)
Feature C → depends on A
Feature D → depends on A, B
Feature E → depends on C, D
```

---

## Phase 3: Decompose Features into Tasks

For EACH feature, generate 3-7 atomic tasks. Each task must be:

- **One-shottable** — Claude can complete it in a single session
- **Testable** — You can verify it works
- **Scoped** — Touches a clear set of files

Format:

```markdown
## Feature: [Name]

- [ ] [Task 1] — [what to build, which files]
- [ ] [Task 2] — [what to build, which files]
- [ ] [Task 3] — [what to build, which files]
```

### Task Quality Check

Before outputting, verify each task against:

| Check | Pass? |
|-------|-------|
| Can Claude one-shot this? | If no → break it down further |
| Is the scope clear? | If no → specify files/functions |
| Can you test it? | If no → add acceptance criteria |
| Does it depend on another task? | If yes → mark the dependency |

### Execution-Grade Task Blocks (Optional)

When tasks will be dispatched to sub-agents (Sonnet teammates, Codex, Kimi) or need maximum specificity, upgrade task blocks to execution-grade. The bar: **a builder should never need to ask a clarifying question.**

Use when:
- Dispatching to external agents via `/dispatch-plan` or `/triad`
- Using Claude Code agent teams (`TeamCreate`)
- Tasks touch unfamiliar codebases or complex integrations

Format for execution-grade tasks:

```markdown
## Task: [Name]

**Files to create/modify:**
- `src/path/to/file.ts` — [what to create or change]
- `src/path/to/other.ts` — [what to create or change]

**Interfaces/Types:**
```ts
// Key types the builder needs (from existing codebase or new)
interface UserPayload {
  id: string;
  email: string;
  role: 'admin' | 'user';
}
```

**Skeleton:**
```ts
// Starting point — builder fills in implementation
export function validateUser(payload: UserPayload): Result<User, ValidationError> {
  // 1. Check email format
  // 2. Verify role is valid
  // 3. Return User or error
}
```

**Test Cases:**
| Test | Input | Expected Output |
|------|-------|-----------------|
| Valid user | `{ id: "1", email: "a@b.com", role: "user" }` | `Ok(User)` |
| Invalid email | `{ id: "1", email: "bad", role: "user" }` | `Err(InvalidEmail)` |
| Missing role | `{ id: "1", email: "a@b.com" }` | `Err(MissingField)` |

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- [ ] All test cases pass
- [ ] No new dependencies added
- [ ] Follows existing error handling pattern in `src/errors.ts`
```

**When NOT to use execution-grade:** Standard `/forge` runs where Claude has full context. Over-specifying wastes time when the builder can read the codebase.

---

## Phase 4: Scale Decision

Count features and assess independence:

| Project Size | Features | Independent? | Approach |
|-------------|----------|--------------|----------|
| **Small** | 1-3 | — | Sequential. Just work through tasks in order. |
| **Medium** | 4-6 | Some | Sequential with suggested groupings. |
| **Large** | 7+ | Yes | Parallel. Suggest `/parallel-forge` with worktree mapping. |

### When to Suggest Worktrees

Suggest `/parallel-forge` when ALL of these are true:
- 5+ features
- At least 3 features are independent (no shared dependencies)
- Features touch different files (minimal conflict risk)

Output a worktree mapping:

```markdown
## Parallel Implementation Plan

### Worktree 1: [feature-a]
Branch: `forge/project/feature-a`
Tasks: [list]
Files owned: [list]

### Worktree 2: [feature-b]
Branch: `forge/project/feature-b`
Tasks: [list]
Files owned: [list]

### Sequential (after merge):
- Feature C (depends on A)
- Feature D (depends on A + B)

### Merge Order: feature-a, feature-b → feature-c → feature-d
```

If the project is small, skip this entirely. Don't over-engineer a 3-feature project with worktrees.

---

## Phase 5: Write Files

### Always Create:

**`$PROJECT_ROOT/SPEC.md`** — The spec document

```markdown
---
created: [date]
status: active
---

# [Project Name] Spec

## What it does
[From interview]

## Who it's for
[From interview]

## Core features
1. [Feature]
2. [Feature]
...

## Constraints
[From interview]

## Done when
- [ ] [Criterion 1]
- [ ] [Criterion 2]
- [ ] [Criterion 3]
```

**`$PROJECT_ROOT/productivity/TODO.md`** — Tasks by feature

```markdown
# TODO

## Feature: [Name] (no deps)
- [ ] [Task 1]
- [ ] [Task 2]
- [ ] [Task 3]

## Feature: [Name] (depends on: Feature A)
- [ ] [Task 1]
- [ ] [Task 2]

## Implementation Order
1. [Feature A] — start here
2. [Feature B] — parallel with A
3. [Feature C] — after A completes
```

### For Large Projects (worktree path), Also Create:

**`$PROJECT_ROOT/DECOMPOSITION.md`** — Worktree plan (consumed by `/parallel-forge scaffold`)

This follows the parallel-forge template format with units, dependencies, merge order, and file ownership.

---

## Output

After all phases, output:

```
## Spec Complete: [Project Name]

**Features:** [count]
**Tasks:** [count]
**Approach:** Sequential | Parallel ([N] worktrees)

### Implementation Order
1. [Feature] — [task count] tasks
2. [Feature] — [task count] tasks (depends on #1)
...

### Files Created
- SPEC.md — product spec
- productivity/TODO.md — task breakdown
[- DECOMPOSITION.md — worktree plan (if parallel)]

### Next Step
[If project has 3+ features OR external APIs OR multiple viable approaches]:
  "Run `/design` to make architecture decisions before building."
[If UI project]:
  "Run `/design` for architecture, then `/design-explore` for visual direction."
[If simple, sequential]:
  "Start with Feature 1. Run: help me implement [first task]"
[If parallel]:
  "Run `/design` first, then `/parallel-forge scaffold [project] [units]` to create worktrees"
```

---

## Updating a Spec

If the project already has a SPEC.md:

```bash
/spec                    # Detects existing SPEC.md, asks what changed
/spec add-feature        # Add a new feature + decompose
/spec re-scope           # Revisit constraints or cut features
```

Read the existing spec, show it, ask what's changed. Update SPEC.md and regenerate affected tasks in TODO.md.

---

## Constraints

- **5-minute exercise** — Don't let spec capture drag on. If answers aren't clear, that's a signal to `/clarify` first.
- **No over-engineering** — 3-feature project gets a TODO, not a DECOMPOSITION.md with worktrees.
- **Tasks must be one-shottable** — If Claude can't finish it in one session, it's too big.
- **Spec is living** — Update it as you build. It's a reference, not a contract.
- **Files stay in the project** — SPEC.md and TODO.md live in the repo, not in Kosha Prime.

---

## Integration with Other Skills

| Trigger | Skill | Why |
|---------|-------|-----|
| AI project detected | Surface AI Interaction Atlas | Think through AI tasks, human tasks, constraints |
| React + AI-generated UI | Surface json-render | Guardrailed generative UI framework |
| 5+ independent features | Suggest `/parallel-forge` | Worktree-based parallel implementation |
| Unclear vision | Suggest `/clarify` first | Sharpen thinking before speccing |
| New project | Run after `/scaffold-project` | Scaffold structure, then spec features |
| 3+ features or external APIs | Suggest `/design` next | Architecture decisions before building |
| UI project | Suggest `/design` then `/design-explore` | Architecture + visual direction |
| Complex feature | Suggest `/forge` | Single-feature autonomous implementation |

---

## Examples

### Small Project (Sequential)

```
/spec

## Spec Complete: price-alert-bot

**Features:** 3
**Tasks:** 9
**Approach:** Sequential

### Implementation Order
1. Price fetcher — 3 tasks
2. Alert rules engine — 3 tasks (depends on #1)
3. Notification sender — 3 tasks (depends on #2)

### Next Step
Start with Feature 1. Run: "help me implement the price fetcher"
```

### Large Project (Parallel)

```
/spec

## Spec Complete: Tutelage

**Features:** 7
**Tasks:** 28
**Approach:** Parallel (4 worktrees)

### Implementation Order
Parallel: content-engine, quiz-system, progress-tracker, settings-ui
Sequential (after merge): adaptive-engine (depends on quiz + progress), parent-dashboard (depends on progress), onboarding (depends on all)

### Next Step
Run `/parallel-forge scaffold tutelage content-engine,quiz-system,progress-tracker,settings-ui`
```

OK so the src/ directory is the default Vite scaffold — no real code yet. The actual components are in the Downloads folder (the extracted zip). Let me now decompose the features based on the clarity brief and the component code I've already read.

Let me think about features and their dependencies:

**Core Features:**

1. **Supabase Schema & Client** — Foundation. Everything else depends on this.
   - Create tables: signal_statuses, signal_data_points, signal_history, live_data_cache, assessments
   - Set up Supabase client
   - Seed with initial data from the JSX files
   
2. **UI Foundation** — I need to port the existing JSX components into the src directory, set up routing between them, and establish the shared styling and data layer that connects everything to Supabase for reading signal data.

3. **FRED API Integration** — Pull in live macroeconomic indicators like M2 velocity, labor share, GDP, JOLTS, consumer confidence, federal receipts, and deficit through a daily polling hook, then map those series to my signal definitions and cache them in Supabase.

4. **Stock Price Feed** — Live...

Continuing with the stock prices for BX, APO, KKR, SNOW, NOW, CRM, and ZS on a 15-minute polling schedule during market hours, cached in Supabase.

5. **Crypto/Stablecoin Feed** — Pull stablecoin market caps and major crypto prices from CoinGecko every 5 minutes and cache those in Supabase as well.

6. **Auto-Threshold Engine** — This is where the logic lives—comparing incoming live data against my threshold definitions to automatically flip signal statuses between green, amber, and red while preserving any manual overrides, then logging those changes to signal_history.

7. **Telegram Alerts** — Set up a Supabase Edge Function that triggers whenever signal_history gets a new entry, integrating with Telegram Bot API for notifications and falling back to email via Resend if needed.

8. **Claude**

Now I'm mapping out the Claude integration piece—using the /signal-update skill for quick threshold adjustments and connecting directly to Supabase for more complex analysis work.

Looking at the dependency graph, the Supabase schema is the foundation with no dependencies, the UI can start with static data and wire up to Supabase later, then the data feeds (FRED, stocks, crypto) all depend on the schema being in place, the threshold engine needs all three feeds plus the schema, and the Telegram alerts layer depends on both the schema and the threshold engine working.

Actually, I'm realizing the parallelization potential here—Features 1 and 2 can happen simultaneously, then 3, 4, and 5 can all run in parallel once the schema exists, Feature 6 needs the schema plus at least one data feed, Feature 7 depends on 6, and Feature 8 can mostly run alongside everything since it just needs Supabase access. With 8 features and at least 3 independent tracks, this definitely qualifies for parallel work.

Now I'm thinking through file ownership for the worktrees—Feature 1 owns the migrations and Supabase utilities, Feature 2 owns the component structure and main app files.

Mapping out the remaining features and their file dependencies...

The data feed features share similar patterns, so I'll batch them together rather than parallelize. I'm settling on three worktrees: one for Supabase schema and client setup, another for the UI layer with routing and styling, and a third for all the data integrations. After those merge, I can tackle the threshold engine, Telegram alerts, and the Claude Code skill sequentially since they depend on earlier work. Now I'll draft the SPEC.md and TODO.md to lay out the full plan.

---

# Asymmetric Bridge Spec

## What it does
Personal strategic intelligence dashboard that merges live macro data feeds (FRED, stock prices, crypto) with manual thesis tracking. Six-domino cascade model tracks interconnected signals for an AI-driven economic disruption thesis. Lucid Box business section maps macro context to personal career/business positioning. Auto-threshold engine flips signal statuses when data crosses defined thresholds, with manual override via Claude Code. Telegram alerts fire on threshold breaches. Full signal history tracked over time.

## Who it's for
Fabian Aguilar (v1 — personal "supreme" instance). Later: knowledge workers and solopreneurs preparing for AI-driven economic shifts (v2 — open-source framework with onboarding wizard).

## Core features
1. **Supabase Foundation** — Schema, client, seed data for all persistence
2. **UI Foundation** — Port existing JSX components, React Router, shared styles
3. **FRED API Integration** — Live economic data (M2, JOLTS, GDP, labor share, yields, consumer confidence, deficit)
4. **Stock Price Feed** — Live prices for BX, APO, KKR, SNOW, NOW, CRM, ZS (15min polling)
5. **Crypto/Stablecoin Feed** — CoinGecko for stablecoin volume + major crypto (5min polling)
6. **Auto-Threshold Engine** — Compare live data vs. defined thresholds, auto-flip statuses, preserve manual overrides
7. **Telegram Alerts** — Bot notification on threshold breaches, email fallback via Supabase Edge Function
8. **Claude Code Integration** — `/signal-update` ALOS skill + direct Supabase access for analysis sessions

## Constraints
- Free-tier APIs only (FRED free key, CoinGecko free, stock API free tier)
- Supabase free tier for persistence (500MB, 50K monthly active users)
- Vite + React (no TypeScript in v1 — match existing JSX convention)
- Vercel deployment (free tier, env vars for API keys)
- Desktop-first design, responsive but not mobile-optimized
- No user auth in v1 (single-user personal instance)
- IBM Plex Sans/Mono fonts, dark theme (#0D0D0F), existing color system

## Done when
- [ ] Dashboard loads with live data (stock prices, FRED macro, crypto) auto-populated and signal statuses reflect current thresholds
- [ ] Telegram notification fires within 60 seconds when a signal crosses a threshold, with correct domino/signal context
- [ ] Claude Code can update any signal status, add data points, and write assessments via `/signal-update` skill, with changes persisted and visible in UI immediately
- [ ] All signal status changes are timestamped in history and viewable in the UI
- [ ] Full Command Center (products, ALOS, Twitter, revenue, content), Signal Tracker (6 dominos, 24 signals), and Source Materials (4 sources + synthesis) are functional and Supabase-backed

## Feature Dependency Graph

```
Feature 1: Supabase Foundation ──────────────────────────────────┐
Feature 2: UI Foundation ─────────────────────────────────────┐  │
Feature 3: FRED API ─────────────── depends on 1 ──────────┐ │  │
Feature 4: Stock Feed ──────────── depends on 1 ──────────┐│ │  │
Feature 5: Crypto Feed ─────────── depends on 1 ─────────┐││ │  │
Feature 6: Auto-Threshold ──────── depends on 1,2,3,4,5 ─┘┘┘─┘──┘
Feature 7: Telegram Alerts ─────── depends on 1,6
Feature 8: Claude Code Integration ─ depends on 1
```

Parallel groups:
- **Group A (parallel):** Feature 1, Feature 2
- **Group B (parallel, after 1):** Feature 3, Feature 4, Feature 5, Feature 8
- **Group C (sequential, after A+B):** Feature 6
- **Group D (sequential, after C):** Feature 7

# TODO — Asymmetric Bridge

## Setup (Pipeline Phase 0-3)
- [x] Run /scaffold-project
- [x] Run /clarify for vision clarity
- [x] Run /spec to decompose features
- [ ] Run /design for architecture decisions

---

## Feature 1: Supabase Foundation (no deps)

- [ ] Create Supabase project + get connection credentials
- [ ] Write migration: signal_statuses table (domino_id, signal_name, status, notes, is_override, updated_at, updated_by)
- [ ] Write migration: signal_data_points table (domino_id, signal_name, date, value, status, source, created_at)
- [ ] Write migration: signal_history table (domino_id, signal_name, old_status, new_status, trigger_type [auto|manual], reason, changed_at)
- [ ] Write migration: live_data_cache table (data_key, data jsonb, fetched_at, ttl_minutes)
- [ ] Write migration: assessments table (section, assessment, confidence, updated_at)
- [ ] Create src/lib/supabase.js — client init with env vars (VITE_SUPABASE_URL, VITE_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY)
- [ ] Seed signal_statuses with initial data from existing JSX (24 signals, current green/amber statuses)
- [ ] Seed assessments with source material assessments from existing JSX

**Files:** `supabase/migrations/*.sql`, `supabase/seed.sql`, `src/lib/supabase.js`
**Acceptance:** Supabase tables exist, seed data queryable, client connects from Vite dev server

---

## Feature 2: UI Foundation (no deps)

- [ ] Extract shared data into src/data/ — dominos.js, products.js, sources.js, twitter.js, revenue.js, comparison.js
- [ ] Extract shared styles into src/styles.js — S object, STATUS_CFG, Badge component
- [ ] Port CommandCenter component → src/components/CommandCenter.jsx (import from data/, wire sections)
- [ ] Port SourceMaterials component → src/components/SourceMaterials.jsx (import from data/)
- [ ] Extract sub-components: SignalCard.jsx, DominoSection.jsx
- [ ] Set up React Router in App.jsx — / → CommandCenter, /sources → SourceMaterials
- [ ] Add nav header with route switching between Command Center and Source Materials
- [ ] Replace Vite default index.css with global dark theme styles (body bg, font imports, scrollbar)
- [ ] Clean up Vite boilerplate (remove App.css, default assets, demo content)

**Files:** `src/data/*.js`, `src/styles.js`, `src/components/*.jsx`, `src/App.jsx`, `src/index.css`, `src/main.jsx`
**Acceptance:** Both pages render correctly with static data, navigation works, matches original JSX visual output

---

## Feature 3: FRED API Integration (depends on: 1)

- [ ] Get FRED API key (free registration at fred.stlouisfed.org)
- [ ] Create src/lib/fred.js — FRED API client with series fetch, error handling, rate limit awareness
- [ ] Map FRED series IDs to signal definitions:
  - M2 velocity (M2V), labor share (PRS85006173), GDP (GDP), JOLTS professional services (JTS540099000000000JOL),
    consumer confidence (CSCICP03USM665S), federal receipts (FGRECPT), initial claims (ICSA),
    information sector employment (CES5000000001)
- [ ] Create src/hooks/useFredData.js — polling hook (daily check), caches in Supabase live_data_cache
- [ ] Parse FRED JSON responses into {date, value, status} format compatible with signal_data_points

**Files:** `src/lib/fred.js`, `src/hooks/useFredData.js`
**Acceptance:** FRED data fetches successfully, parses into signal-compatible format, caches in Supabase, stale cache triggers refetch

---

## Feature 4: Stock Price Feed (depends on: 1)

- [ ] Select stock API — Twelve Data (800 free req/day) or Alpha Vantage (25/day) — configure in .env
- [ ] Create src/lib/stocks.js — fetch quotes for [BX, APO, KKR, SNOW, NOW, CRM, ZS], batch where possible
- [ ] Create src/hooks/useStockData.js — 15min polling during market hours (9:30-4 ET), no polling off-hours
- [ ] Map stock data to signal definitions (PE-backed software → SNOW/NOW/CRM prices, alt managers → BX/APO/KKR)
- [ ] Cache in Supabase live_data_cache with 15min TTL

**Files:** `src/lib/stocks.js`, `src/hooks/useStockData.js`
**Acceptance:** Stock prices load and display, polling respects market hours, cache prevents redundant API calls

---

## Feature 5: Crypto/Stablecoin Feed (depends on: 1)

- [ ] Create src/lib/crypto.js — CoinGecko free API client (no key for basic tier)
- [ ] Fetch stablecoin market cap (USDT, USDC, DAI aggregate) + total stablecoin volume
- [ ] Fetch alt manager tokens / major crypto for general market sentiment
- [ ] Create src/hooks/useCryptoData.js — 5min polling, cache in Supabase live_data_cache
- [ ] Map crypto data to Domino 3 signals (stablecoin transaction volume threshold)

**Files:** `src/lib/crypto.js`, `src/hooks/useCryptoData.js`
**Acceptance:** Stablecoin volume and market cap display, 5min refresh, CoinGecko rate limits respected

---

## Feature 6: Auto-Threshold Engine (depends on: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

- [ ] Create src/lib/threshold-engine.js — define threshold rules per signal (operator, value, status mapping)
- [ ] Build evaluation logic: compare live_data_cache values against threshold definitions
- [ ] Auto-update signal_statuses when thresholds crossed (only if is_override = false)
- [ ] Preserve manual overrides: if is_override = true, skip auto-update for that signal
- [ ] Write to signal_history on every status change (old_status, new_status, trigger_type, reason with data value)
- [ ] Create src/hooks/useAutoThreshold.js — runs evaluation after each data feed update
- [ ] Wire into UI: CommandCenter reads signal_statuses from Supabase instead of static data

**Files:** `src/lib/threshold-engine.js`, `src/hooks/useAutoThreshold.js`, updates to `src/components/CommandCenter.jsx`
**Acceptance:** Signals auto-flip when data crosses thresholds, manual overrides preserved, history records all changes with timestamps

---

## Feature 7: Telegram Alerts (depends on: 1, 6)

- [ ] Create Telegram bot via @BotFather, get bot token + chat ID
- [ ] Create Supabase Edge Function: supabase/functions/signal-alert/index.ts
- [ ] Set up Supabase database webhook: trigger on signal_history INSERT
- [ ] Format Telegram message: "🔴 [Domino N] [Signal Name] flipped [old] → [new]. Reason: [data value]. Threshold: [threshold def]"
- [ ] Add email fallback: if Telegram fails, send via Resend API
- [ ] Store bot token + chat ID as Supabase secrets (not in client code)

**Files:** `supabase/functions/signal-alert/index.ts`, Supabase dashboard configuration
**Acceptance:** Telegram notification received within 60 seconds of signal status change, includes domino context and threshold data

---

## Feature 8: Claude Code Integration (depends on: 1)

- [ ] Create ALOS skill: .claude/skills/signal-update/SKILL.md
- [ ] Skill usage: `/signal-update domino:2 signal:JOLTS status:red notes:"collapsed below 1.5M"`
- [ ] Skill writes to signal_statuses (is_override=true), signal_data_points, and signal_history via Supabase API
- [ ] Support bulk updates: `/signal-update review` — walk through all signals, suggest status changes
- [ ] Document direct Supabase access pattern for complex analysis sessions (read/write tables via Claude Code)

**Files:** `.claude/skills/signal-update/SKILL.md`, documentation in CLAUDE.md
**Acceptance:** `/signal-update` modifies Supabase data, changes appear in UI on refresh, history records manual updates with "claude-code" attribution

---

## Implementation Order

### Parallel Group A (start immediately):
1. **Feature 1: Supabase Foundation** — schema, client, seed
2. **Feature 2: UI Foundation** — port components, routing, styles

### Parallel Group B (after Feature 1 completes):
3. **Feature 3: FRED API** — economic data feeds
4. **Feature 4: Stock Feed** — financial market data
5. **Feature 5: Crypto Feed** — CoinGecko stablecoin data
6. **Feature 8: Claude Code Integration** — /signal-update skill

### Sequential (after Group A + B merge):
7. **Feature 6: Auto-Threshold Engine** — intelligence layer
8. **Feature 7: Telegram Alerts** — notification system

### Deploy:
9. Vercel deployment + env var configuration
