- [ ] Extract shared styles into src/styles.js — S object, STATUS_CFG, Badge component
- [ ] Port CommandCenter component → src/components/CommandCenter.jsx (import from data/, wire sections)
- [ ] Port SourceMaterials component → src/components/SourceMaterials.jsx (import from data/)
- [ ] Extract sub-components: SignalCard.jsx, DominoSection.jsx
- [ ] Set up React Router in App.jsx — / → CommandCenter, /sources → SourceMaterials
- [ ] Add nav header with route switching between Command Center and Source Materials
- [ ] Replace Vite default index.css with global dark theme styles (body bg, font imports, scrollbar)
- [ ] Clean up Vite boilerplate (remove App.css, default assets, demo content)

**Files:** `src/data/*.js`, `src/styles.js`, `src/components/*.jsx`, `src/App.jsx`, `src/index.css`, `src/main.jsx`
**Acceptance:** Both pages render correctly with static data, navigation works, matches original JSX visual output

---

## Feature 3: FRED API Integration (depends on: 1)

- [ ] Get FRED API key (free registration at fred.stlouisfed.org)
- [ ] Create src/lib/fred.js — FRED API client with series fetch, error handling, rate limit awareness
- [ ] Map FRED series IDs to signal definitions:
  - M2 velocity (M2V), labor share (PRS85006173), GDP (GDP), JOLTS professional services (JTS540099000000000JOL),
    consumer confidence (CSCICP03USM665S), federal receipts (FGRECPT), initial claims (ICSA),
    information sector employment (CES5000000001)
- [ ] Create src/hooks/useFredData.js — polling hook (daily check), caches in Supabase live_data_cache
- [ ] Parse FRED JSON responses into {date, value, status} format compatible with signal_data_points

**Files:** `src/lib/fred.js`, `src/hooks/useFredData.js`
**Acceptance:** FRED data fetches successfully, parses into signal-compatible format, caches in Supabase, stale cache triggers refetch

---

## Feature 4: Stock Price Feed (depends on: 1)

- [ ] Select stock API — Twelve Data (800 free req/day) or Alpha Vantage (25/day) — configure in .env
- [ ] Create src/lib/stocks.js — fetch quotes for [BX, APO, KKR, SNOW, NOW, CRM, ZS], batch where possible
- [ ] Create src/hooks/useStockData.js — 15min polling during market hours (9:30-4 ET), no polling off-hours
- [ ] Map stock data to signal definitions (PE-backed software → SNOW/NOW/CRM prices, alt managers → BX/APO/KKR)
- [ ] Cache in Supabase live_data_cache with 15min TTL

**Files:** `src/lib/stocks.js`, `src/hooks/useStockData.js`
**Acceptance:** Stock prices load and display, polling respects market hours, cache prevents redundant API calls

---

## Feature 5: Crypto/Stablecoin Feed (depends on: 1)

- [ ] Create src/lib/crypto.js — CoinGecko free API client (no key for basic tier)
- [ ] Fetch stablecoin market cap (USDT, USDC, DAI aggregate) + total stablecoin volume
- [ ] Fetch alt manager tokens / major crypto for general market sentiment
- [ ] Create src/hooks/useCryptoData.js — 5min polling, cache in Supabase live_data_cache
- [ ] Map crypto data to Domino 3 signals (stablecoin transaction volume threshold)

**Files:** `src/lib/crypto.js`, `src/hooks/useCryptoData.js`
**Acceptance:** Stablecoin volume and market cap display, 5min refresh, CoinGecko rate limits respected

---

## Feature 6: Auto-Threshold Engine (depends on: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

- [ ] Create src/lib/threshold-engine.js — define threshold rules per signal (operator, value, status mapping)
- [ ] Build evaluation logic: compare live_data_cache values against threshold definitions
- [ ] Auto-update signal_statuses when thresholds crossed (only if is_override = false)
- [ ] Preserve manual overrides: if is_override = true, skip auto-update for that signal
- [ ] Write to signal_history on every status change (old_status, new_status, trigger_type, reason with data value)
- [ ] Create src/hooks/useAutoThreshold.js — runs evaluation after each data feed update
- [ ] Wire into UI: CommandCenter reads signal_statuses from Supabase instead of static data

**Files:** `src/lib/threshold-engine.js`, `src/hooks/useAutoThreshold.js`, updates to `src/components/CommandCenter.jsx`
**Acceptance:** Signals auto-flip when data crosses thresholds, manual overrides preserved, history records all changes with timestamps

---

## Feature 7: Telegram Alerts (depends on: 1, 6)

- [ ] Create Telegram bot via @BotFather, get bot token + chat ID
- [ ] Create Supabase Edge Function: supabase/functions/signal-alert/index.ts
- [ ] Set up Supabase database webhook: trigger on signal_history INSERT
- [ ] Format Telegram message: "🔴 [Domino N] [Signal Name] flipped [old] → [new]. Reason: [data value]. Threshold: [threshold def]"
- [ ] Add email fallback: if Telegram fails, send via Resend API
- [ ] Store bot token + chat ID as Supabase secrets (not in client code)

**Files:** `supabase/functions/signal-alert/index.ts`, Supabase dashboard configuration
**Acceptance:** Telegram notification received within 60 seconds of signal status change, includes domino context and threshold data

---

## Feature 8: Claude Code Integration (depends on: 1)

- [ ] Create ALOS skill: .claude/skills/signal-update/SKILL.md
- [ ] Skill usage: `/signal-update domino:2 signal:JOLTS status:red notes:"collapsed below 1.5M"`
- [ ] Skill writes to signal_statuses (is_override=true), signal_data_points, and signal_history via Supabase API
- [ ] Support bulk updates: `/signal-update review` — walk through all signals, suggest status changes
- [ ] Document direct Supabase access pattern for complex analysis sessions (read/write tables via Claude Code)

**Files:** `.claude/skills/signal-update/SKILL.md`, documentation in CLAUDE.md
**Acceptance:** `/signal-update` modifies Supabase data, changes appear in UI on refresh, history records manual updates with "claude-code" attribution

---

## Implementation Order

### Parallel Group A (start immediately):
1. **Feature 1: Supabase Foundation** — schema, client, seed
2. **Feature 2: UI Foundation** — port components, routing, styles

### Parallel Group B (after Feature 1 completes):
3. **Feature 3: FRED API** — economic data feeds
4. **Feature 4: Stock Feed** — financial market data
5. **Feature 5: Crypto Feed** — CoinGecko stablecoin data
6. **Feature 8: Claude Code Integration** — /signal-update skill

### Sequential (after Group A + B merge):
7. **Feature 6: Auto-Threshold Engine** — intelligence layer
8. **Feature 7: Telegram Alerts** — notification system

### Deploy:
9. Vercel deployment + env var configuration

---

## Spec Complete: Asymmetric Bridge

**Features:** 8
**Tasks:** 48
**Approach:** Parallel (4 worktrees) + 2 sequential

### Implementation Order
| Phase | Features | Tasks | Parallel? |
|-------|----------|-------|-----------|
| Group A | Supabase Foundation, UI Foundation | 18 | Yes (2 worktrees) |
| Group B | FRED API, Stock Feed, Crypto Feed, Claude Code Integration | 18 | Yes (2 worktrees, after Supabase merges) |
| Group C | Auto-Threshold Engine | 7 | Sequential (needs all above) |
| Group D | Telegram Alerts | 6 | Sequential (needs threshold engine) |
| Deploy | Vercel config | — | After all features |

### Files Created
- `SPEC.md` — product spec with dependency graph
- `productivity/TODO.md` — 48 tasks across 8 features
- `DECOMPOSITION.md` — 4-worktree parallel forge plan

### Next Step
Run `/design` to lock architecture decisions before building — specifically:
- Supabase schema details (RLS policies, indexes)
- Threshold rule format (how to define auto-flip rules declaratively)
- Data feed → signal mapping (which FRED series maps to which domino signal)
- Component state management (React context vs. prop drilling for live data)

Then: `/parallel-forge scaffold asymmetric-bridge supabase,ui,data-feeds,claude-integration`

Base directory for this skill: /Users/fabianaguilar/Projects/ALOS/.claude/skills/design

# /design — First-Principles Design Document

Produce a formal design document between spec and implementation. Every constraint gets evaluated, every approach gets justified. No implementation begins without an approved design.

## Philosophy

The gap between spec and code is where bad decisions hide. `/spec` captures *what* to build. `/design` captures *why this approach* and *what alternatives were rejected*. Without it, architectural decisions get made implicitly inside forge loops — unauditable, unrepeatable, and often wrong.

## Usage

```bash
/design                        # Start design from existing SPEC.md
/design from <file>            # Design from a specific spec or brief
/design review                 # Review existing ARCHITECTURE.md for staleness
```

## Pipeline Position

```
/clarify → /spec → ★ /design ★ → /adversarial-review → /forge or /dispatch-plan
```

This skill is MANDATORY for:
- Any project with 3+ features
- Any project involving external APIs or third-party libraries
- Any project where multiple architectural approaches are viable

SKIP for: Single-file scripts, config changes, documentation-only work.

---

## Phase 1: Load Context

1. Read `SPEC.md` (or provided file) — extract features, constraints, acceptance criteria
2. Read project's existing codebase patterns (if any):
   - `package.json` / `Cargo.toml` / `pyproject.toml` — tech stack
   - Existing source structure — naming conventions, module patterns
   - `CLAUDE.md` (project-level) — any project-specific rules
3. Read relevant ALOS context:
   - `.claude/context/code-standards.md` — quality requirements

---

## Phase 2: Constraint Classification

For EVERY constraint from the spec, classify:

| Constraint | Type | Classification | Justification |
|-----------|------|----------------|---------------|
| [constraint] | Hard / Soft | Immovable / Negotiable / Assumed | [why this classification] |

**Hard constraints** = non-negotiable (platform, budget, security, regulatory)
**Soft constraints** = preferences or assumptions that could be challenged

**Flag any soft constraint being treated as hard.** This is the #1 source of over-engineering.

Present constraint table to user. Ask:
> "I've classified your constraints. Any of these wrong? Anything I'm treating as hard that's actually flexible?"

---

## Phase 3: Research Approaches

For the core architectural decision(s), research:

1. **Codebase patterns** — Grep/Glob for how similar problems are solved in this project or other ALOS projects
2. **Library/framework options** — WebSearch for current best practices (include year in search)
3. **Known pitfalls** — Search for common failure modes of each approach

For each viable approach, document:

```markdown
### Approach [N]: [Name]

**How it works:** [2-3 sentences]
**Constraints satisfied:** [list which constraints this satisfies]
**Constraints violated:** [list which constraints this breaks, if any]
**Tradeoffs:**
- Pro: [advantage]
- Pro: [advantage]
- Con: [disadvantage]
- Con: [disadvantage]
**Effort estimate:** [Low / Medium / High]
**Confidence:** [HIGH / MEDIUM / LOW]
```

Research at least 2 approaches. 3 is ideal. More than 4 means the problem space isn't well-defined — go back to `/clarify`.

---

## Phase 4: Select and Justify

Choose the recommended approach. Justify with:

1. **Why this one** — direct connection to constraints and goals
2. **Why not the others** — specific reasons each alternative was rejected
3. **Risk mitigation** — what could go wrong and how to detect it early
4. **Reversibility** — how hard is it to switch if this turns out wrong?

---

## Phase 5: Component Map

Translate the chosen approach into a concrete file/component structure:

```markdown
## Component Map

### New Files
- `src/[path]/[file]` — [purpose, ~LOC estimate]
- `src/[path]/[file]` — [purpose, ~LOC estimate]

### Modified Files
- `src/[path]/[file]` — [what changes and why]

### Dependencies
- [package@version] — [why needed]

### Data Flow
[How data moves through the system — can be text or ASCII diagram]
```

---

## Phase 6: Write ARCHITECTURE.md

Output location: `$PROJECT_ROOT/ARCHITECTURE.md`

> **Note:** This file was previously named `DESIGN.md`. Renamed to `ARCHITECTURE.md` to avoid collision with `/design-extract`, which writes the visual design system to `DESIGN.md`. Architecture = how it works. Design = how it looks.

```markdown
---
created: [date]
spec: SPEC.md
status: pending-review
---

# Architecture: [Project/Feature Name]

## Summary
[2-3 sentences: what we're building and the chosen approach]

## Constraint Classification

| Constraint | Type | Classification | Justification |
|-----------|------|----------------|---------------|
| ... | ... | ... | ... |

## Approaches Considered

### Approach 1: [Name] (SELECTED)
[Full writeup from Phase 3]

### Approach 2: [Name] (REJECTED)
[Full writeup from Phase 3]
**Rejection reason:** [specific reason]

### Approach 3: [Name] (REJECTED)
[Full writeup from Phase 3]
**Rejection reason:** [specific reason]

## Decision Rationale
[From Phase 4 — why this approach, why not others, risks, reversibility]

## Component Map
[From Phase 5]

## Open Questions
[Anything unresolved that /adversarial-review should stress-test]

## Next Step
Run `/adversarial-review` on this document, or proceed to `/forge` if adversarial review is not warranted.
```

---

## Phase 7: Approval Gate

Present the design to the user:

```markdown
## Design Complete: [Name]

**Approach:** [chosen approach name]
**Alternatives rejected:** [count]
**Constraints classified:** [count] ([hard count] hard, [soft count] soft)
**Open questions:** [count]

**Files created:** ARCHITECTURE.md

### Next Steps
1. `/adversarial-review` — stress-test this design (recommended for complex projects)
2. `/forge` or `/dispatch-plan` — proceed to implementation
3. Discuss — talk through concerns before committing
```

Use AskUserQuestion to get direction.

---

## Integration with Other Skills

| Trigger | Skill | Why |
|---------|-------|-----|
| Fuzzy vision | `/clarify` first | Design needs clear intent |
| After design approval | `/adversarial-review` | Stress-test before building |
| After design approval (simple) | `/forge` | Direct to implementation |
| Multi-agent project | `/dispatch-plan` | Classify tasks across agents |
| Design involves UI | Include `/frontend-design` notes | Design pipeline alignment |

---

## Constraints

- **Not a spec.** `/spec` captures what. `/design` captures how and why. Don't re-ask spec questions.
- **Not a plan.** `/design` is architecture. `/spec` Phase 3 (or enhanced task blocks) is the execution plan.
- **Research is mandatory.** Don't skip web search. The point is to ground decisions in current reality, not cached knowledge.

---
created: 2026-02-22
status: active
---

# Asymmetric Bridge Spec

## What it does
Personal strategic intelligence dashboard that merges live macro data feeds (FRED, stock prices, crypto) with manual thesis tracking. Six-domino cascade model tracks interconnected signals for an AI-driven economic disruption thesis. Lucid Box business section maps macro context to personal career/business positioning. Auto-threshold engine flips signal statuses when data crosses defined thresholds, with manual override via Claude Code. Telegram alerts fire on threshold breaches. Full signal history tracked over time.

## Who it's for
Fabian Aguilar (v1 — personal "supreme" instance). Later: knowledge workers and solopreneurs preparing for AI-driven economic shifts (v2 — open-source framework with onboarding wizard).

## Core features
1. **Supabase Foundation** — Schema, client, seed data for all persistence
2. **UI Foundation** — Port existing JSX components, React Router, shared styles
3. **FRED API Integration** — Live economic data (M2, JOLTS, GDP, labor share, yields, consumer confidence, deficit)
4. **Stock Price Feed** — Live prices for BX, APO, KKR, SNOW, NOW, CRM, ZS (15min polling)
5. **Crypto/Stablecoin Feed** — CoinGecko for stablecoin volume + major crypto (5min polling)
6. **Auto-Threshold Engine** — Compare live data vs. defined thresholds, auto-flip statuses, preserve manual overrides
7. **Telegram Alerts** — Bot notification on threshold breaches, email fallback via Supabase Edge Function
8. **Claude Code Integration** — `/signal-update` ALOS skill + direct Supabase access for analysis sessions

## Constraints
- Free-tier APIs only (FRED free key, CoinGecko free, stock API free tier)
- Supabase free tier for persistence (500MB, 50K monthly active users)
- Vite + React (no TypeScript in v1 — match existing JSX convention)
- Vercel deployment (free tier, env vars for API keys)
- Desktop-first design, responsive but not mobile-optimized
- No user auth in v1 (single-user personal instance)
- IBM Plex Sans/Mono fonts, dark theme (#0D0D0F), existing color system

## Done when
- [ ] Dashboard loads with live data (stock prices, FRED macro, crypto) auto-populated and signal statuses reflect current thresholds
- [ ] Telegram notification fires within 60 seconds when a signal crosses a threshold, with correct domino/signal context
- [ ] Claude Code can update any signal status, add data points, and write assessments via `/signal-update` skill, with changes persisted and visible in UI immediately
- [ ] All signal status changes are timestamped in history and viewable in the UI
- [ ] Full Command Center (products, ALOS, Twitter, revenue, content), Signal Tracker (6 dominos, 24 signals), and Source Materials (4 sources + synthesis) are functional and Supabase-backed

## Feature Dependency Graph

```
Feature 1: Supabase Foundation ──────────────────────────────────┐
Feature 2: UI Foundation ─────────────────────────────────────┐  │
Feature 3: FRED API ─────────────── depends on 1 ──────────┐ │  │
Feature 4: Stock Feed ──────────── depends on 1 ──────────┐│ │  │
Feature 5: Crypto Feed ─────────── depends on 1 ─────────┐││ │  │
Feature 6: Auto-Threshold ──────── depends on 1,2,3,4,5 ─┘┘┘─┘──┘
Feature 7: Telegram Alerts ─────── depends on 1,6
Feature 8: Claude Code Integration ─ depends on 1
```

Parallel groups:
- **Group A (parallel):** Feature 1, Feature 2
- **Group B (parallel, after 1):** Feature 3, Feature 4, Feature 5, Feature 8
- **Group C (sequential, after A+B):** Feature 6
- **Group D (sequential, after C):** Feature 7

input.prompt:
Research the best current approaches for these specific architectural decisions in a Vite + React project (no TypeScript). Return concise findings for each:

1. **React data fetching for polling/live data (2025-2026)**: What's the current best practice for polling APIs at different intervals in React? Compare: raw useEffect + setInterval, TanStack Query (React Query) with refetchInterval, SWR with refreshInterval, or custom hooks. Which handles stale-while-revalidate, cache invalidation, and error retry best?

2. **Supabase client-side patterns**: Best way to use Supabase in a Vite React app — direct client calls from components vs. custom hooks wrapping Supabase queries. Any gotchas with Supabase JS v2 in Vite?

3. **Free stock price APIs (2026)**: What free stock APIs are available? Compare Alpha Vantage (25 req/day free), Twelve Data (800 req/day free), Yahoo Finance (unofficial), Financial Modeling Prep (250 req/day free). Which is most reliable for getting quotes for ~7 tickers with 15-minute refresh?

4. **FRED API usage**: How to batch multiple FRED series in one call. Rate limits. Best practices for caching economic data that updates monthly/quarterly.

5. **Telegram Bot API for alerts**: How to send messages from a Supabase Edge Function to a Telegram bot. Architecture: database webhook trigger → Edge Function → Telegram sendMessage. Any gotchas?

Be specific and practical — code patterns over theory. Include any version-specific notes for 2025/2026.

I've completed the web search with your query about free stock price APIs. Here are the key findings:

## Rate Limits Comparison

**Alpha Vantage:**
- Free tier is limited to 25 requests per day
- As of 2025, the free tier allows up to 25 API requests per day covering most datasets

**Twelve Data:**
- Free tier gives you 800 calls per day
- Free (Basic): 8 API requests per minute (up to ~800/day)

**Yahoo Finance:**
- It's technically free with no official rate limits, but it's also unofficial — it scrapes Yahoo's endpoints, may violate their terms of service, and breaks frequently

**Other Notable Providers:**
- Finnhub offers the most generous free tier at 60 requests per minute
- Polygon.io's free tier gives you 5 calls per minute

## Key Advantages

- Alpha Vantage wins on technical indicators (50+ pre-computed) and is currently the only provider with an official, vendor-maintained MCP server for AI/LLM integration
- Twelve Data has wide global exchange coverage and includes WebSocket streaming

The search results indicate that while Alpha Vantage has stricter rate limits on its free tier, it offers comprehensive technical analysis features and strong reliability, whereas Twelve Data provides more generous free quotas and global market access.

I found several relevant resources on Supabase with React, Vite, and custom hooks. Here's a summary of the search results:

## Key Patterns and Best Practices

**Setup & Configuration:**
Create a React app using a Vite template with the supabase-js client library, which provides a convenient interface for working with Supabase from a React app.

**Directory Structure:**
Follow a modular structure that separates concerns, including directories for components, pages, services (with supabase.ts for client initialization, auth.ts for authentication, and database.ts for database interactions), utils, types, hooks, and styles.

**Custom Hooks for Data Fetching:**
react-supabase is a React Hooks library for Supabase that provides hooks like `useRealtime`. The Infinite Query Hook is a single React hook that makes it easier to load data progressively from your Supabase database, handling data fetching and pagination state for infinite lists or tables.

**Real-time Patterns:**
Real-time updates can be implemented using Supabase React hooks, with changes in database tables reflected live without requiring a page refresh through Supabase's real-time subscription feature.

**Architectural Anti-patterns to Avoid:**
Avoid direct database access from UI components, as this tightly couples the UI to the database and makes testing difficult—instead, use a service layer to abstract database interactions.

**Advanced Patterns:**
Advanced React patterns include using Compound-components for modals and menus, and TanStack Query (React Query) for fetching and posting data to the Supabase API.

I've performed the web search on React polling API best practices with a focus on 2025 developments comparing TanStack Query, SWR, useEffect, and setInterval. Here are the key findings:

## Key Comparisons

### TanStack Query vs Traditional useEffect + setInterval

Traditional data fetching with useEffect and useState requires significant boilerplate code for managing loading states, errors, and fetching logic. Using setInterval with manual cleanup can be tedious and error-prone due to interval management and cleanup logic.

### TanStack Query Polling Best Practices

To enable polling in TanStack Query, set the refetchInterval option to specify the interval in milliseconds at which data should be refetched. For background polling, use refetchIntervalInBackground: true to keep polling even when the tab isn't focused.

User-controlled polling can toggle on and off with state for complete control over when data fetches.

### TanStack Query vs SWR (2025)

TanStack Query includes DevTools for debugging and has a larger plugin ecosystem, while SWR doesn't have official DevTools. Feature-wise, they're pretty comparable, with main differences in API design and bundle size rather than capabilities.

### When to Use Each Approach

If it's API/server data, use TanStack Query; if it's UI side effects or browser subscriptions, use useEffect. useEffect can fetch data but quickly turns into repeated boilerplate with loading/error state and cleanup logic, while TanStack Query provides a cleaner default with built-in caching and refetching.

Which handles stale-while-revalidate, cache invalidation, and error retry best?

Based on the search results, here's what I found about integrating Telegram Bot API with Supabase Edge Functions and webhooks:

## Architecture Overview

Edge Functions are server-side TypeScript functions, distributed globally at the edge—close to your users. They can be used for listening to webhooks or integrating your Supabase project with third-parties like Stripe.

## Telegram Bot with Supabase Edge Functions

Supabase provides support for building a Telegram Bot with Edge Functions, using the grammY framework to handle Telegram Bot webhooks. grammY is an open source Telegram Bot Framework which makes it easy to handle and respond to incoming messages.

## Webhook Trigger Setup

To implement this architecture:

1. **Deploy the Edge Function**: Set your bot's webhook URL to https://<PROJECT_REFERENCE>.functions.supabase.co/telegram-bot

2. **Configure Telegram Webhook**: The webhook is configured by calling the Telegram setWebhook endpoint with a URL format like https://api.telegram.org/bot<BOT_TOKEN>/setWebhook?url=https://<PROJECT_REFERENCE_ID>.supabase.co/functions/v1/telegram-bot?secret=<BOT_TOKEN>

3. **Security Consideration**: JWT authorization must be disabled because Telegram uses a different way to make sure the requests are coming from Telegram.

## Alternative Workflow Approach

For database webhooks triggering Telegram messages, integration services can create workflows with a Supabase trigger and Telegram Bot action that run on their servers 24x7.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Twelve Data's free tier, request limits, and API reliability for 2025-2026:

## Free Tier Details

Twelve Data's free tier gives you 800 calls per day, which is actually usable for development and small projects. This is also confirmed by another source noting that the free (basic) plan allows 8 API requests per minute (up to ~800/day), which gives real-time data for US stocks, forex, and crypto.

## API Reliability

Twelve Data advertises 99.95% uptime, and in experience, they deliver. According to recent assessments, Twelve Data has become a go-to recommendation for developers who need reliability over rock-bottom pricing.

## General Characteristics

Twelve Data focuses on global market coverage and ease of integration. It supports stocks, forex, crypto and ETFs and is known for clean data, clear documentation and strong multi-region support. The API also offers reliable WebSocket feeds with comprehensive documentation.

## Limitations on Free Tier

The main limitation is that free users get limited historical data - typically just a few years. Additionally, certain features (like WebSocket streaming or extended history) are limited on the free tier.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about FRED API batch requests, rate limits, and caching best practices:

## Rate Limits

The FRED API rate limit is 120 requests per minute. The API has a rate limit of 120 requests per minute.

## Batching Multiple Series in a Single Call

While the search results don't specifically document a dedicated batch endpoint for retrieving multiple series in one call, the general principle applies: Batching puts multiple operations into one API call instead of sending them separately. Many APIs offer batch endpoints that let you send multiple operations in one request, and you should always check the API documentation for batch endpoints before building loops.

## Caching Best Practices

Caching can reduce repeated API hits when working with data that doesn't change often, and storing previously retrieved responses using tools like Redis or in-memory caching improves performance and lowers the number of calls.

For the FRED API specifically, when working with large or repeated FRED queries, enabling caching can significantly speed up your workflow and reduce the number of redundant API requests, and fedfred supports built-in caching using cachetools with cached responses stored on disk and automatically re-used when appropriate.

## Rate Limit Handling

FedFred automatically respects rate limits (~120 calls/minute), and if the FRED rate limit is hit, fredr functions will wait an appropriate amount of time before automatically attempting to make the request again, with a wait of 20 seconds between failed attempts and a maximum of 6 failed attempts.

# TanStack Query v5 Polling API

Based on the provided content, here's what's documented about polling configuration:

## Core API Options

The article mentions setting **`refetchInterval`** to specify polling frequency in milliseconds:

> "simply set the `refetchInterval` option to specify the interval (in milliseconds) at which the data should be refetched"

## Code Pattern Example

The guide demonstrates basic polling:

```jsx
const { data, isLoading, error } = useQuery({
  queryKey: ['data'],
  queryFn: () => fetch('/api/data').then(r => r.json()),
  refetchInterval: 5000 // polls every 5 seconds
});
```

## Advanced Features Mentioned

**Dynamic Intervals**: The content references using a function for `refetchInterval` that receives current data, enabling conditional polling logic based on freshness requirements.

**Window Focus Control**: The documentation notes `refetchOnWindowFocus` can restrict polling to active user interaction periods, reducing unnecessary network requests.

## Important Note

The provided content doesn't explicitly document `refetchIntervalInBackground` or other v5-specific options. For complete API documentation including background polling behavior, you should consult the [official TanStack Query documentation](https://tanstack.com/query/latest).

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding your query about FRED API, rate limits, and fetching multiple series:

## Key Findings:

**Rate Limit:** The FRED API has a rate limit of 120 requests per minute.

**No Batch Endpoint:** The FRED API does not have a dedicated batch endpoint for fetching multiple series in a single request. Users have asked if there is a way to query all (or multiple) series in one request so they're not pinging the FRED API many times, but the standard API design requires separate calls for each series.

**Individual Series Approach:** The API is designed for series-level queries. The FRED API Version 1 provides incremental data on a series level and can be customized according to data source, release, category, series, and other preferences.

## Best Approaches for Rate-Limited Scenarios:

1. **Sequential Calls with Throttling:** Throttle requests to stay under the 120 requests per minute limit - for example, placing a throttle tool before the download tool and throttling to 100 records per minute, with each record being one FRED Series.

2. **Async/Concurrent Requests:** Fetch multiple series in parallel with AsyncAPI to greatly improve speed. This allows you to make multiple requests concurrently while respecting the aggregate rate limit.

3. **Implement Caching and Retry Logic:** When hitting the rate limit of 120 requests/minute, the recommended approach is to wait before retrying the request.

For managing 120+ series efficiently, the best approach would be to combine throttling with asynchronous requests to maximize throughput while staying within the rate limit constraints.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Supabase database webhooks, Edge Functions, and pg_net HTTP request patterns:

## Overview

pg_net is an async networking extension for Postgres that allows you to trigger external payloads on database events. PG_NET powers Supabase's Webhook functionality.

## How It Works

pg_net enables Postgres to make asynchronous HTTP/HTTPS requests in SQL. It differs from the http extension in that it is asynchronous by default, making it useful in blocking functions (like triggers).

## HTTP Request Pattern for Edge Functions

The typical pattern for triggering Supabase Edge Functions from PostgreSQL using pg_net is:

Using `net.http_post()` with the Edge Function URL (e.g., `https://project-ref.supabase.co/functions/v1/function-name`) and including authorization headers with your anon key.

## Key Implementation Details

- The PG_NET extension eliminates the need for servers to continuously poll for database changes and instead allows the database to proactively notify external resources about significant events, seamlessly integrating with triggers, cron jobs (e.g., PG_CRON), and procedures.

- Do not add triggers to the net._http_response or net.http_request_queue tables, as these special tables can cause infinite loops if triggers on them fail or call pg_net functions.

- pg_net can only make POST requests with JSON data, and is intended to handle at most 200 requests per second.

content.content:
# Database Webhook to Edge Function Setup

## SQL Trigger Pattern

According to the Supabase documentation, here's the exact SQL syntax:

```sql
create trigger "my_webhook" after insert
on "public"."my_table" for each row
execute function "supabase_functions"."http_request"(
  'http://host.docker.internal:3000',
  'POST',
  '{"Content-Type":"application/json"}',
  '{}',
  '1000'
);
```

## Edge Function URL Format

For local development with Edge Functions specifically, the documentation states: *"if you want to trigger an edge function when a webhook fires, your webhook URL would be:"*

```
http://host.docker.internal:54321/functions/v1/my-function-name
```

## Payload Structure

The webhook automatically generates payloads with this structure for each event type:

**INSERT events** include: `type: 'INSERT'`, `table`, `schema`, `record`, and `old_record: null`

**UPDATE events** contain: `type: 'UPDATE'`, `table`, `schema`, `record`, and the previous `old_record`

**DELETE events** provide: `type: 'DELETE'`, `table`, `schema`, `record: null`, and `old_record`

The important note: *"All events are fired after a database row is changed."*

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about using Supabase Edge Functions to send Telegram messages:

## Overview

Supabase Edge Functions can handle Telegram Bot Webhooks with the grammY framework, which is an open source Telegram Bot Framework that makes it easy to handle and respond to incoming messages.

## Code Example

A basic example using the grammY framework shows: importing Bot and webhookCallback from grammY, getting the bot token from environment variables, creating a bot instance, and defining commands like "start" that reply with messages.

## Key Setup Steps

1. **Create the Function**: Create a new Supabase Function by running `supabase functions new telegram-bot`

2. **Webhook Configuration**: You need to run your bot on webhooks using webhookCallback, not call bot.start() in your code.

3. **Set Webhook URL**: To tell Telegram where to send updates, call the setWebhook endpoint with your function's URL

## Official Resources

Supabase provides documentation and examples on GitHub for building a Telegram Bot, and there are Edge Function Examples available in the Supabase GitHub repository.

For specific recent code examples and complete implementation details, you can visit the official Supabase documentation on Building a Telegram Bot or check the GitHub repository for the latest templates.

content.content:
# Polling Code Comparison: TanStack Query vs SWR

Based on the article provided, here's how the two libraries handle polling:

## TanStack Query (React Query) Approach

```javascript
const { data: user } = useQuery({
  queryKey: ['user', userId],
  queryFn: () => fetchUser(userId),
  staleTime: 5 * 60 * 1000,      // 5 minutes
  cacheTime: 10 * 60 * 1000,     // 10 minutes
})
```

The article demonstrates TanStack Query's configuration model but doesn't explicitly show `refetchInterval` implementation in the provided code samples.

## SWR Polling Implementation

The article displays SWR's polling capabilities more directly:

```javascript
const { data: user } = useSWR(
  `/api/users/${userId}`,
  fetcher,
  {
    refreshInterval: 30000,  // Refresh every 30 seconds
    dedupingInterval: 5000,
    revalidateOnFocus: true,
  }
)
```

## Key Difference

SWR uses **"refreshInterval"** for automatic polling, while the comparison indicates TanStack Query employs more granular cache control through `staleTime` and background refetching mechanisms. SWR's stale-while-revalidate strategy displays cached data immediately while fetching fresh data in the background—a deliberate design philosophy highlighted throughout the guide.

Based on the search results, I found some relevant information about Supabase with Vite, though the specific topic of singleton client issues with HMR and multiple instances is not extensively covered in these results. Here's what I found:

## Vite-Related Gotchas with Supabase

There is a known Rollup/Vite limitation with re-exported external imports that affects Supabase. If you see UNUSED_EXTERNAL_IMPORT warnings from Vite/Nuxt, these are false positives, and the npm documentation provides workarounds using rollupOptions configuration.

## Client Instantiation Pattern

The common pattern in Vite projects is to create a singleton Supabase client. A typical setup exports a single client instance: `export const supabase = createClient(supabaseUrl, supabaseAnonKey)`

## HMR and Session Management

While the search results don't explicitly address HMR-related issues with multiple client instances, they do mention that supabase-js uses local storage only for session storage and will only work on a server or on a browser but not both, which could be relevant when dealing with module reloading during development.

The search results don't contain specific documentation about HMR gotchas or singleton/multiple instance issues with Supabase JS v2 in Vite for 2024-2025. For more detailed information on these specific concerns, you may want to check the official Supabase GitHub discussions or issues, or the Vite documentation on handling module replacement patterns.

# Financial Data APIs: Free Tier Comparison

Based on the article, here's how these providers compare for your use case:

**Alpha Vantage**
- Free tier: 25 calls/day (severely limited)
- "The jump from free to paid is steep" - paid plans start at $49.99/month
- Data quality is solid with 20+ years of history
- Support is sparse

**Twelve Data**
- Free tier: 800 calls/day (actually usable)
- 99.95% uptime reliability
- Transparent pricing; paid tiers up to $329/month
- Excellent documentation

**Financial Modeling Prep**
- Free tier: 250 requests/day
- Specializes in fundamental data (SEC filings)
- Better for analysis than real-time quotes

**Yahoo Finance**
- Not covered in this article

## Best for Your Needs

For polling a small number of tickers every 15 minutes, **Twelve Data** emerges as the winner. With 800 daily calls available free, you could easily handle dozens of tickers with polling intervals. The article notes it offers "the best balance between features and reliability," making it ideal for small-scale, consistent data needs without enterprise costs.

**Alpha Vantage** is impractical for ongoing polling due to its restrictive free tier.

content.thinking:
Excellent research. Now I have strong data for the architecture decisions. Let me synthesize this into the design document.

Key decisions:1. **Data fetching:** TanStack Query v5 — clear winner for polling dashboard
2. **Supabase client:** Singleton + custom hooks (not direct component calls)
3. **Stock API:** Twelve Data — batch symbols, 800/day fits our use case
4. **FRED:** Promise.all parallel calls, 24h staleTime, no polling
5. **Telegram:** DB webhook → Edge Function → sendMessage6. **State management:** TanStack Query handles all server state; React state only for UI state (tabs, expanded items)Now let me write the ARCHITECTURE.md.


I'm weighing two main approaches for the threshold engine: running evaluations client-side when the dashboard loads versus using a scheduled Edge Function that operates independently. Client-side is simpler but only triggers when someone's actively viewing, while the Edge Function approach runs continuously but adds complexity with cron management.

The key insight is that for Telegram alerts to actually work, I need the threshold engine running in the background regardless of whether the dashboard is open—otherwise alerts would only fire when someone's already looking at it, which defeats the purpose. So I need at minimum a Supabase cron function that fetches live data from FRED, stocks, and crypto sources, evaluates the thresholds, and writes results to signal_history to trigger the webhook.

The tradeoff is that this creates duplication—the data fetching and threshold logic would exist both client-side and in the edge function. But the right approach is to accept that duplication: the client-side handles real-time updates when the dashboard is active, while the cron function runs on a schedule to catch everything else. Both write to the same tables, so the Telegram webhook fires regardless of which source triggered the signal.

I should also note that I need to add TanStack Query as a dependency recommendation, then move on to writing out the full architecture.

content.text:
Research is solid. Now let me classify constraints and write the architecture.

## Phase 2: Constraint Classification

| Constraint | Type | Classification | Justification |
|-----------|------|----------------|---------------|
| Free-tier APIs only | **Hard** | Immovable | Budget constraint, personal project |
| Supabase free tier | **Soft** | Negotiable | Could upgrade to $25/mo Pro if needed — 500MB is plenty for this use case though |
| Vite + React, no TypeScript | **Hard** | Immovable | Match existing JSX components, keep v1 velocity high |
| Vercel deployment | **Soft** | Negotiable | Could use Netlify or self-host, but Vercel + Vite is zero-config |
| Desktop-first | **Hard** | Immovable | This is a workstation tool |
| No user auth | **Soft** | Assumed | Single user, but Vercel password protect adds a layer. Could add Supabase auth later for open-source version |
| IBM Plex + dark theme + color system | **Hard** | Immovable | Visual identity already established in source components |
| Telegram primary alerts | **Soft** | Negotiable | Could switch to email-only or Discord. Telegram chosen for speed/convenience |
| Signal history tracking | **Hard** | Immovable | Core feature — needed for trend analysis and audit trail |

One thing I'm flagging: **"no TypeScript" is being treated as hard, but it's actually soft.** The existing JSX has no types, but TanStack Query (the recommended data layer) has excellent TS support and the DX is significantly better with types. For v1 velocity, JSX is fine. Worth revisiting for v2 open-source.

Now let me write the full architecture document.

input.content:
---
created: 2026-02-22
spec: SPEC.md
status: pending-review
---

# Architecture: Asymmetric Bridge

## Summary
Personal strategic intelligence dashboard built with Vite + React + Supabase. TanStack Query v5 manages all data fetching with per-source polling intervals. Live data from Twelve Data (stocks), FRED (macro), and CoinGecko (crypto) feeds into a client-side auto-threshold engine that flips signal statuses. A parallel Supabase cron job runs the same threshold evaluation when the dashboard isn't open, ensuring Telegram alerts fire 24/7. Claude Code integration via dedicated ALOS skill writes to the same Supabase tables for manual overrides and analysis.

## Constraint Classification

| Constraint | Type | Classification | Justification |
|-----------|------|----------------|---------------|
| Free-tier APIs only | Hard | Immovable | Budget constraint, personal project |
| Supabase free tier | Soft | Negotiable | Could upgrade to $25/mo Pro if needed |
| Vite + React, no TypeScript | Hard | Immovable | Match existing JSX, keep v1 velocity high |
| Vercel deployment | Soft | Negotiable | Vercel + Vite is zero-config, best DX |
| Desktop-first | Hard | Immovable | Workstation tool |
| No user auth | Soft | Assumed | Single user v1, Supabase auth available for v2 |
| IBM Plex + dark theme | Hard | Immovable | Visual identity established in source JSX |
| Telegram alerts | Soft | Negotiable | Best balance of speed and simplicity |
| Signal history tracking | Hard | Immovable | Core feature for trend analysis |

## Key Architectural Decisions

---

### Decision 1: Data Fetching Strategy

#### Approach 1: TanStack Query v5 (SELECTED)

**How it works:** Each data source gets a `useQuery` hook with source-specific `refetchInterval`. TanStack Query handles caching, stale-while-revalidate, error retry, and deduplication. Different polling cadences coexist naturally.

**Constraints satisfied:** All — free, works in Vite, no server needed
**Tradeoffs:**
- Pro: Built-in cache, retry, dedup, devtools
- Pro: Per-query polling intervals (15min stocks, 5min crypto, daily FRED)
- Pro: `staleTime` means instant renders from cache while background refetch happens
- Pro: Can persist cache to localStorage for cross-session survival
- Con: Adds ~13KB to bundle (acceptable for a dashboard)
**Effort:** Low — drop-in replacement for raw useEffect
**Confidence:** HIGH

#### Approach 2: SWR (REJECTED)

**How it works:** Vercel's stale-while-revalidate library. Similar API to TanStack Query.
**Rejection reason:** Weaker on query invalidation, no DevTools in v1, no function-based refetchInterval. TanStack Query is strictly better for a multi-source polling dashboard.

#### Approach 3: Raw useEffect + setInterval (REJECTED)

**How it works:** Manual polling in each component with cleanup in useEffect.
**Rejection reason:** Unmaintainable. No built-in retry, dedup, cache, or stale detection. Would require reimplementing what TanStack Query provides for free.

---

### Decision 2: Stock Price API

#### Approach 1: Twelve Data (SELECTED)

**How it works:** REST API with batch symbol support. One request fetches all 7 tickers. 800 calls/day free tier.

**Constraints satisfied:** Free tier (800/day), reliable (99.95% uptime)
**Tradeoffs:**
- Pro: Batch symbols in one call — 7 tickers = 1 API call per interval
- Pro: 800 calls/day → only need ~96/day for 15min polling = massive headroom
- Pro: Clean JSON response, documented API
- Con: Free tier has 8 req/min limit (not a concern for our cadence)
**Effort:** Low
**Confidence:** HIGH

#### Approach 2: Alpha Vantage (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** 25 calls/day free tier is completely unusable for 15-minute polling of 7 tickers.

#### Approach 3: Yahoo Finance (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** Unofficial API, no SLA, breaks randomly, ToS violation. Not suitable for a tool you depend on for decisions.

#### Approach 4: Finnhub (CONSIDERED)

**How it works:** 60 req/min free, WebSocket streaming available.
**Status:** Worth considering for v1.5 if we want real-time streaming. For v1, Twelve Data's batch endpoint is simpler and sufficient.

---

### Decision 3: Threshold Engine Location

#### Approach 1: Hybrid — Client + Supabase Cron (SELECTED)

**How it works:** Two evaluation paths that write to the same Supabase tables:
1. **Client-side:** Runs in the browser after each data fetch. Immediate UI feedback when you're looking.
2. **Supabase cron Edge Function:** Runs every 15 minutes. Fetches data, evaluates thresholds, writes changes. Fires Telegram alerts even when dashboard isn't open.

Both write to `signal_statuses` and `signal_history`. The Telegram webhook triggers on `signal_history` INSERT regardless of source.

**Constraints satisfied:** Alerts work 24/7, UI is always current when open
**Tradeoffs:**
- Pro: Alerts fire even when not looking at dashboard
- Pro: Dashboard stays responsive with immediate client-side evaluation
- Pro: Same threshold definitions used by both — single source of truth
- Con: Data fetching logic exists in both client JS and Deno Edge Function (some duplication)
- Con: Need to handle idempotency — both paths might evaluate the same data
**Effort:** Medium
**Confidence:** HIGH

**Idempotency solution:** Each threshold evaluation checks `signal_statuses.updated_at` — if the current status was updated within the last evaluation window, skip. This prevents double-writes from client and cron evaluating the same data.

#### Approach 2: Client-side only (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** Alerts only fire when dashboard is open. Defeats the purpose of Telegram notifications. If you're not checking the dashboard, you need the alert most.

#### Approach 3: Supabase cron only (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** Dashboard would show stale data until the next cron tick. When you're actively watching the dashboard, you want immediate feedback from fresh data, not 15-minute-old evaluations.

---

### Decision 4: State Management

#### Approach 1: TanStack Query for server state, React useState for UI state (SELECTED)

**How it works:** TanStack Query owns all data that comes from APIs or Supabase (signals, prices, FRED data). React `useState` owns UI-only state (active tab, expanded sections, selected domino). No global state manager needed.

**Constraints satisfied:** Simple, no extra dependencies, scales well for this use case
**Tradeoffs:**
- Pro: Clean separation — server state in query cache, UI state in components
- Pro: No Redux/Zustand/Jotai overhead
- Pro: TanStack Query cache IS the global state for data
- Con: If UI state needs to be shared across deeply nested components, prop drilling could get messy
**Effort:** Low
**Confidence:** HIGH

**Prop drilling mitigation:** The existing JSX already uses prop drilling and it works fine for the component depth. If v2 open-source needs shared UI state (e.g., user config), add React Context then.

#### Approach 2: Zustand (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** Adds a dependency for a problem we don't have. The data layer (TanStack Query) handles 90% of state. UI state is shallow. Over-engineering.

---

### Decision 5: Supabase Schema Design

#### Tables

```sql
-- Signal statuses (current state of each signal)
create table signal_statuses (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  domino_id int not null,
  signal_name text not null,
  status text not null check (status in ('green', 'amber', 'red')),
  notes text,
  is_override boolean default false,
  updated_at timestamptz default now(),
  updated_by text default 'system',
  unique(domino_id, signal_name)
);

-- Signal data points (specific measurements over time)
create table signal_data_points (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  domino_id int not null,
  signal_name text not null,
  date text not null,
  value text not null,
  status text not null check (status in ('green', 'amber', 'red')),
  source text,
  created_at timestamptz default now()
);

-- Signal history (audit trail of all status changes)
create table signal_history (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  domino_id int not null,
  signal_name text not null,
  old_status text not null,
  new_status text not null,
  trigger_type text not null check (trigger_type in ('auto', 'manual', 'cron')),
  reason text,
  changed_at timestamptz default now()
);

-- Live data cache (external API responses)
create table live_data_cache (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  data_key text unique not null,
  data jsonb not null,
  fetched_at timestamptz default now(),
  ttl_minutes int default 60
);

-- Assessments (qualitative analysis from Claude Code)
create table assessments (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  section text unique not null,
  assessment text not null,
  confidence text check (confidence in ('HIGH', 'MEDIUM', 'LOW', 'UNVERIFIED')),
  updated_at timestamptz default now()
);

-- Indexes for common queries
create index idx_signal_statuses_domino on signal_statuses(domino_id);
create index idx_signal_history_changed_at on signal_history(changed_at desc);
create index idx_signal_history_domino on signal_history(domino_id, signal_name);
create index idx_live_data_cache_key on live_data_cache(data_key);
create index idx_live_data_cache_fetched on live_data_cache(fetched_at);
```

**No RLS policies in v1.** Single user, no auth. The anon key has full access. For v2 open-source, add RLS with Supabase auth.

**Why `text` for signal values instead of `numeric`:** Signal data comes from heterogeneous sources — some are numbers (118% NRR), some are ranges ("1.5M-2M"), some are qualitative ("3 consecutive months"). Storing as text preserves the original format. Threshold evaluation parses as needed.

---

### Decision 6: Threshold Rule Format

Thresholds are defined declaratively as JSON objects alongside signal definitions:

```js
// Example threshold rule
{
  signal_name: "M2 Velocity of Money",
  fred_series: "M2V",
  thresholds: [
    { operator: "<", value: 1.0, status: "red", reason: "Below 1.0 = money not circulating" },
    { operator: "<", value: 1.2, status: "amber", reason: "Approaching critical threshold" },
    // Default: green (no rule matched)
  ],
  evaluation_order: "first_match" // Evaluate top to bottom, first match wins
}
```

Rules evaluate top-to-bottom. First match wins. No match = green (baseline).

For signals without live data feeds (e.g., "Y Combinator batch analysis"), thresholds are `manual_only: true` — only updated via Claude Code.

---

## Component Map

### New Dependencies
- `@tanstack/react-query` — data fetching + caching + polling

### New Files

```
src/
├── lib/
│   ├── supabase.js          — Supabase singleton client (~15 LOC)
│   ├── fred.js              — FRED API client, series fetch, parallel batch (~60 LOC)
│   ├── stocks.js            — Twelve Data client, batch quotes (~50 LOC)
│   ├── crypto.js            — CoinGecko client, stablecoin + market cap (~50 LOC)
│   └── threshold-engine.js  — Rule evaluator, status comparator, history writer (~120 LOC)
├── hooks/
│   ├── useFredData.js       — TanStack Query hook, daily staleTime (~30 LOC)
│   ├── useStockData.js      — TanStack Query hook, 15min refetchInterval, market hours aware (~40 LOC)
│   ├── useCryptoData.js     — TanStack Query hook, 5min refetchInterval (~30 LOC)
│   ├── useSignalStatuses.js — TanStack Query hook, reads from Supabase signal_statuses (~25 LOC)
│   └── useAutoThreshold.js  — Orchestrator: runs threshold engine after data fetches (~50 LOC)
├── data/
│   ├── dominos.js           — Static domino definitions + threshold rules (~200 LOC)
│   ├── products.js          — Lucid Box product data (~80 LOC)
│   ├── sources.js           — Source material data (~100 LOC)
│   ├── comparison.js        — Thesis comparison data (~40 LOC)
│   ├── twitter.js           — Twitter pillar data (~30 LOC)
│   └── revenue.js           — Revenue scenario data (~40 LOC)
├── styles.js                — Shared styles, STATUS_CFG, Badge component (~50 LOC)
├── components/
│   ├── CommandCenter.jsx    — Main dashboard (adapted from source JSX) (~300 LOC)
│   ├── SourceMaterials.jsx  — Thesis comparison (adapted from source JSX) (~150 LOC)

## FRED Series → Signal Mapping

| Signal | FRED Series ID | Domino |
|--------|---------------|--------|
| M2 Velocity of Money | M2V | 4: Ghost GDP |
| Labor Share of GDP | PRS85006173 | 4: Ghost GDP |
| GDP Growth | GDP | 4: Ghost GDP |
| JOLTS: Prof. Services Openings | JTS540099000000000JOL | 2: White-Collar |
| Initial Jobless Claims | ICSA | 2: White-Collar |
| Information Sector Employment | CES5000000001 | 2: White-Collar |
| Consumer Confidence | CSCICP03USM665S | 4: Ghost GDP |
| Federal Receipts | FGRECPT | 6: Policy Response |

## Stock Ticker → Signal Mapping

| Tickers | Signal | Domino |
|---------|--------|--------|
| BX, APO, KKR | Alt Manager Stock Prices | 5: Financial Contagion |
| SNOW, NOW, CRM, ZS | Public SaaS (proxy for NRR health) | 1: SaaS Compression |

## Crypto → Signal Mapping

| Data | Signal | Domino |
|------|--------|--------|
| USDT + USDC + DAI market cap | Stablecoin Transaction Volume | 3: Friction Collapse |

## Open Questions

1. **Supabase cron frequency:** 15 minutes matches stock polling, but FRED data only updates monthly. Should the cron job have different schedules for different data types, or is a single 15-minute sweep simpler and sufficient?
   - **Recommendation:** Single 15-minute sweep. The FRED fetch is cheap (cached locally), and the evaluation logic skips unchanged values. Simplicity wins.

2. **Twelve Data API key exposure:** The Twelve Data API key is in client-side code (VITE_ prefix). This is fine for a personal dashboard but would need a backend proxy for the open-source version.
   - **Recommendation:** Accept for v1. Document the proxy pattern in AGENTS.md for v2.

3. **Signal history UI:** The spec says "viewable in the UI" but the existing JSX has no history component. How prominent should history be?
   - **Recommendation:** Small expandable timeline inside each SignalCard. Show last 5 status changes with timestamps. Keep it minimal — the data is there for analysis, not constant viewing.

## Risk Mitigation

| Risk | Detection | Mitigation |
|------|-----------|------------|
| Twelve Data free tier rate limit hit | 429 response codes | TanStack Query retry with backoff. Cache aggressively. Batch is 1 call not 7. |
| Supabase Edge Function cold starts | Alert delivery >60 seconds | Keep function warm with a health check ping. Telegram API is fast (<1s). |
| Dual threshold evaluation (client + cron) writes duplicate history | Check signal_history for duplicate entries in same window | Idempotency: check `signal_statuses.updated_at` — skip if updated within last evaluation window |
| CoinGecko rate limiting (10-30 req/min free) | 429 responses | 5-minute polling interval is well within limits. Cache aggressively. |
| FRED API key leaked in client | N/A for v1 (personal) | FRED free tier has no billing. Low risk. Proxy in v2. |

## Reversibility Assessment

| Decision | Reversibility | Switch Cost |
|----------|--------------|-------------|
| TanStack Query → SWR | High | Similar API, swap imports. ~2 hours. |
| Twelve Data → Finnhub | High | Change fetch URLs, same data shape. ~1 hour. |
| Supabase → any Postgres | High | Standard SQL, client library swap. ~4 hours. |
| Client threshold → cron-only | High | Delete client hooks, cron handles all. ~2 hours. |
| Telegram → Discord/Slack | High | Change webhook URL in Edge Function. ~30 min. |

All decisions are highly reversible. No lock-in.

## Next Step
Run `/adversarial-review` on this document, or proceed to `/forge` if adversarial review is not warranted.

toolUseResult.content:
---
created: 2026-02-22
spec: SPEC.md
status: pending-review
---

# Architecture: Asymmetric Bridge

## Summary
Personal strategic intelligence dashboard built with Vite + React + Supabase. TanStack Query v5 manages all data fetching with per-source polling intervals. Live data from Twelve Data (stocks), FRED (macro), and CoinGecko (crypto) feeds into a client-side auto-threshold engine that flips signal statuses. A parallel Supabase cron job runs the same threshold evaluation when the dashboard isn't open, ensuring Telegram alerts fire 24/7. Claude Code integration via dedicated ALOS skill writes to the same Supabase tables for manual overrides and analysis.

## Constraint Classification

| Constraint | Type | Classification | Justification |
|-----------|------|----------------|---------------|
| Free-tier APIs only | Hard | Immovable | Budget constraint, personal project |
| Supabase free tier | Soft | Negotiable | Could upgrade to $25/mo Pro if needed |
| Vite + React, no TypeScript | Hard | Immovable | Match existing JSX, keep v1 velocity high |
| Vercel deployment | Soft | Negotiable | Vercel + Vite is zero-config, best DX |
| Desktop-first | Hard | Immovable | Workstation tool |
| No user auth | Soft | Assumed | Single user v1, Supabase auth available for v2 |
| IBM Plex + dark theme | Hard | Immovable | Visual identity established in source JSX |
| Telegram alerts | Soft | Negotiable | Best balance of speed and simplicity |
| Signal history tracking | Hard | Immovable | Core feature for trend analysis |

## Key Architectural Decisions

---

### Decision 1: Data Fetching Strategy

#### Approach 1: TanStack Query v5 (SELECTED)

**How it works:** Each data source gets a `useQuery` hook with source-specific `refetchInterval`. TanStack Query handles caching, stale-while-revalidate, error retry, and deduplication. Different polling cadences coexist naturally.

**Constraints satisfied:** All — free, works in Vite, no server needed
**Tradeoffs:**
- Pro: Built-in cache, retry, dedup, devtools
- Pro: Per-query polling intervals (15min stocks, 5min crypto, daily FRED)
- Pro: `staleTime` means instant renders from cache while background refetch happens
- Pro: Can persist cache to localStorage for cross-session survival
- Con: Adds ~13KB to bundle (acceptable for a dashboard)
**Effort:** Low — drop-in replacement for raw useEffect
**Confidence:** HIGH

#### Approach 2: SWR (REJECTED)

**How it works:** Vercel's stale-while-revalidate library. Similar API to TanStack Query.
**Rejection reason:** Weaker on query invalidation, no DevTools in v1, no function-based refetchInterval. TanStack Query is strictly better for a multi-source polling dashboard.

#### Approach 3: Raw useEffect + setInterval (REJECTED)

**How it works:** Manual polling in each component with cleanup in useEffect.
**Rejection reason:** Unmaintainable. No built-in retry, dedup, cache, or stale detection. Would require reimplementing what TanStack Query provides for free.

---

### Decision 2: Stock Price API

#### Approach 1: Twelve Data (SELECTED)

**How it works:** REST API with batch symbol support. One request fetches all 7 tickers. 800 calls/day free tier.

**Constraints satisfied:** Free tier (800/day), reliable (99.95% uptime)
**Tradeoffs:**
- Pro: Batch symbols in one call — 7 tickers = 1 API call per interval
- Pro: 800 calls/day → only need ~96/day for 15min polling = massive headroom
- Pro: Clean JSON response, documented API
- Con: Free tier has 8 req/min limit (not a concern for our cadence)
**Effort:** Low
**Confidence:** HIGH

#### Approach 2: Alpha Vantage (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** 25 calls/day free tier is completely unusable for 15-minute polling of 7 tickers.

#### Approach 3: Yahoo Finance (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** Unofficial API, no SLA, breaks randomly, ToS violation. Not suitable for a tool you depend on for decisions.

#### Approach 4: Finnhub (CONSIDERED)

**How it works:** 60 req/min free, WebSocket streaming available.
**Status:** Worth considering for v1.5 if we want real-time streaming. For v1, Twelve Data's batch endpoint is simpler and sufficient.

---

### Decision 3: Threshold Engine Location

#### Approach 1: Hybrid — Client + Supabase Cron (SELECTED)

**How it works:** Two evaluation paths that write to the same Supabase tables:
1. **Client-side:** Runs in the browser after each data fetch. Immediate UI feedback when you're looking.
2. **Supabase cron Edge Function:** Runs every 15 minutes. Fetches data, evaluates thresholds, writes changes. Fires Telegram alerts even when dashboard isn't open.

Both write to `signal_statuses` and `signal_history`. The Telegram webhook triggers on `signal_history` INSERT regardless of source.

**Constraints satisfied:** Alerts work 24/7, UI is always current when open
**Tradeoffs:**
- Pro: Alerts fire even when not looking at dashboard
- Pro: Dashboard stays responsive with immediate client-side evaluation
- Pro: Same threshold definitions used by both — single source of truth
- Con: Data fetching logic exists in both client JS and Deno Edge Function (some duplication)
- Con: Need to handle idempotency — both paths might evaluate the same data
**Effort:** Medium
**Confidence:** HIGH

**Idempotency solution:** Each threshold evaluation checks `signal_statuses.updated_at` — if the current status was updated within the last evaluation window, skip. This prevents double-writes from client and cron evaluating the same data.

#### Approach 2: Client-side only (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** Alerts only fire when dashboard is open. Defeats the purpose of Telegram notifications. If you're not checking the dashboard, you need the alert most.

#### Approach 3: Supabase cron only (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** Dashboard would show stale data until the next cron tick. When you're actively watching the dashboard, you want immediate feedback from fresh data, not 15-minute-old evaluations.

---

### Decision 4: State Management

#### Approach 1: TanStack Query for server state, React useState for UI state (SELECTED)

**How it works:** TanStack Query owns all data that comes from APIs or Supabase (signals, prices, FRED data). React `useState` owns UI-only state (active tab, expanded sections, selected domino). No global state manager needed.

**Constraints satisfied:** Simple, no extra dependencies, scales well for this use case
**Tradeoffs:**
- Pro: Clean separation — server state in query cache, UI state in components
- Pro: No Redux/Zustand/Jotai overhead
- Pro: TanStack Query cache IS the global state for data
- Con: If UI state needs to be shared across deeply nested components, prop drilling could get messy
**Effort:** Low
**Confidence:** HIGH

**Prop drilling mitigation:** The existing JSX already uses prop drilling and it works fine for the component depth. If v2 open-source needs shared UI state (e.g., user config), add React Context then.

#### Approach 2: Zustand (REJECTED)

**Rejection reason:** Adds a dependency for a problem we don't have. The data layer (TanStack Query) handles 90% of state. UI state is shallow. Over-engineering.

---

### Decision 5: Supabase Schema Design

#### Tables

```sql
-- Signal statuses (current state of each signal)
create table signal_statuses (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  domino_id int not null,
  signal_name text not null,
  status text not null check (status in ('green', 'amber', 'red')),
  notes text,
  is_override boolean default false,
  updated_at timestamptz default now(),
  updated_by text default 'system',
  unique(domino_id, signal_name)
);

-- Signal data points (specific measurements over time)
create table signal_data_points (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  domino_id int not null,
  signal_name text not null,
  date text not null,
  value text not null,
  status text not null check (status in ('green', 'amber', 'red')),
  source text,
  created_at timestamptz default now()
);

-- Signal history (audit trail of all status changes)
create table signal_history (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  domino_id int not null,
  signal_name text not null,
  old_status text not null,
  new_status text not null,
  trigger_type text not null check (trigger_type in ('auto', 'manual', 'cron')),
  reason text,
  changed_at timestamptz default now()
);

-- Live data cache (external API responses)
create table live_data_cache (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  data_key text unique not null,
  data jsonb not null,
  fetched_at timestamptz default now(),
  ttl_minutes int default 60
);

-- Assessments (qualitative analysis from Claude Code)
create table assessments (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  section text unique not null,
  assessment text not null,
  confidence text check (confidence in ('HIGH', 'MEDIUM', 'LOW', 'UNVERIFIED')),
  updated_at timestamptz default now()
);

-- Indexes for common queries
create index idx_signal_statuses_domino on signal_statuses(domino_id);
create index idx_signal_history_changed_at on signal_history(changed_at desc);
create index idx_signal_history_domino on signal_history(domino_id, signal_name);
create index idx_live_data_cache_key on live_data_cache(data_key);
create index idx_live_data_cache_fetched on live_data_cache(fetched_at);
```

**No RLS policies in v1.** Single user, no auth. The anon key has full access. For v2 open-source, add RLS with Supabase auth.

**Why `text` for signal values instead of `numeric`:** Signal data comes from heterogeneous sources — some are numbers (118% NRR), some are ranges ("1.5M-2M"), some are qualitative ("3 consecutive months"). Storing as text preserves the original format. Threshold evaluation parses as needed.

---

### Decision 6: Threshold Rule Format

Thresholds are defined declaratively as JSON objects alongside signal definitions:

```js
// Example threshold rule
{
  signal_name: "M2 Velocity of Money",
  fred_series: "M2V",
  thresholds: [
    { operator: "<", value: 1.0, status: "red", reason: "Below 1.0 = money not circulating" },
    { operator: "<", value: 1.2, status: "amber", reason: "Approaching critical threshold" },
    // Default: green (no rule matched)
  ],
  evaluation_order: "first_match" // Evaluate top to bottom, first match wins
}
```

Rules evaluate top-to-bottom. First match wins. No match = green (baseline).

For signals without live data feeds (e.g., "Y Combinator batch analysis"), thresholds are `manual_only: true` — only updated via Claude Code.

---

## Component Map

### New Dependencies

| Twelve Data free tier rate limit hit | 429 response codes | TanStack Query retry with backoff. Cache aggressively. Batch is 1 call not 7. |
| Supabase Edge Function cold starts | Alert delivery >60 seconds | Keep function warm with a health check ping. Telegram API is fast (<1s). |
| Dual threshold evaluation (client + cron) writes duplicate history | Check signal_history for duplicate entries in same window | Idempotency: check `signal_statuses.updated_at` — skip if updated within last evaluation window |
| CoinGecko rate limiting (10-30 req/min free) | 429 responses | 5-minute polling interval is well within limits. Cache aggressively. |
| FRED API key leaked in client | N/A for v1 (personal) | FRED free tier has no billing. Low risk. Proxy in v2. |

## Reversibility Assessment

| Decision | Reversibility | Switch Cost |
|----------|--------------|-------------|
| TanStack Query → SWR | High | Similar API, swap imports. ~2 hours. |
| Twelve Data → Finnhub | High | Change fetch URLs, same data shape. ~1 hour. |
| Supabase → any Postgres | High | Standard SQL, client library swap. ~4 hours. |
| Client threshold → cron-only | High | Delete client hooks, cron handles all. ~2 hours. |
| Telegram → Discord/Slack | High | Change webhook URL in Edge Function. ~30 min. |

All decisions are highly reversible. No lock-in.

## Next Step
Run `/adversarial-review` on this document, or proceed to `/forge` if adversarial review is not warranted.

content.text:
---

## Design Complete: Asymmetric Bridge

**Approach:** TanStack Query v5 + Twelve Data + FRED + CoinGecko + Supabase + Hybrid Threshold Engine
**Alternatives rejected:** 6 (SWR, raw useEffect, Alpha Vantage, Yahoo Finance, client-only threshold, cron-only threshold)
**Constraints classified:** 9 (6 hard, 3 soft)
**Open questions:** 3 (all with recommendations)

**Key decisions:**
1. **TanStack Query v5** — polling with per-source intervals, cache, retry, devtools
2. **Twelve Data** — batch 7 tickers in 1 call, 800/day free tier (need ~96)
3. **Hybrid threshold engine** — client-side for immediate UI + Supabase cron for 24/7 alerts
4. **TanStack Query = state manager** — no Redux/Zustand needed
5. **Telegram alerts** via Supabase DB webhook → Edge Function → Bot API

**All decisions are highly reversible.** No lock-in anywhere.

**Files created:** `ARCHITECTURE.md`

The original JSX files are essentially our visual spec — we're adding live data connectivity, not redesigning anything.

content.text:
Great question — let me be explicit about this.

**The original JSX files are the visual spec.** Everything from them carries over:

- Dark theme (`#0D0D0F` background)
- IBM Plex Sans/Mono typography
- Full color system (`#E63946`, `#F4A261`, `#2A9D8F`, `#264653`, `#9B2226`, `#6D6875`, `#E9C46A`)
- Card patterns, expandable sections, signal status badges
- Gradient accent bar, section tabs, domino cascade visualization
- All static data (products, dominos, signals, sources, revenue, Twitter pillars)
- All interactive patterns (expand/collapse, tab switching, status indicators)

**What changes:**
- Data moves from hardcoded arrays → `src/data/` files (same values, just organized)
- Components read signal *statuses* from Supabase instead of static `currentStatus` fields
- Signal cards gain live data display (actual stock prices, FRED values next to thresholds)
- New `SignalHistory` component shows status change timeline inside each signal card
- Navigation moves from internal tab state → React Router (URL-addressable pages)

**Nothing gets lost.** The original JSX is the foundation — we're wiring it up, not redesigning it.

As for the design pipeline — since the visual design already exists in those files, we don't need `/frontend-design` to generate anything new. What we should do:

1. **Build first** (port the components + wire live data)
2. **`/design-review`** after building — Zoom-In Method to catch any quality drops from the port
3. **`/baseline-ui`** — catch any AI slop that crept in

Want to move to implementation? We can either:
- **`/forge`** — sequential, one feature at a time (simpler, I'd recommend starting here)
- **`/parallel-forge`** — 4 worktrees building simultaneously (faster but more merge complexity)

Given this is the first build and features depend on each other, I'd recommend starting with `/forge` on Features 1+2 (Supabase + UI Foundation), then parallelize the data feeds after.

-- Asymmetric Bridge: Signal Tracker Schema
-- Migration 001: Create all tables

-- Signal statuses (current state of each signal)
create table signal_statuses (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  domino_id int not null,
  signal_name text not null,
  status text not null check (status in ('green', 'amber', 'red')),
  notes text,
  is_override boolean default false,
  updated_at timestamptz default now(),
  updated_by text default 'system',
  unique(domino_id, signal_name)
);

-- Signal data points (specific measurements over time)
create table signal_data_points (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  domino_id int not null,
  signal_name text not null,
  date text not null,
  value text not null,
  status text not null check (status in ('green', 'amber', 'red')),
  source text,
  created_at timestamptz default now()
);

-- Signal history (audit trail of all status changes)
create table signal_history (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  domino_id int not null,
  signal_name text not null,
  old_status text not null,
  new_status text not null,
  trigger_type text not null check (trigger_type in ('auto', 'manual', 'cron')),
  reason text,
  changed_at timestamptz default now()
);

-- Live data cache (external API responses)
create table live_data_cache (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  data_key text unique not null,
  data jsonb not null,
  fetched_at timestamptz default now(),
  ttl_minutes int default 60
);

-- Assessments (qualitative analysis from Claude Code)
create table assessments (
  id uuid primary key default gen_random_uuid(),
  section text unique not null,
  assessment text not null,
  confidence text check (confidence in ('HIGH', 'MEDIUM', 'LOW', 'UNVERIFIED')),
  updated_at timestamptz default now()
);

-- Indexes
create index idx_signal_statuses_domino on signal_statuses(domino_id);
create index idx_signal_history_changed_at on signal_history(changed_at desc);
create index idx_signal_history_domino on signal_history(domino_id, signal_name);
create index idx_signal_data_points_domino on signal_data_points(domino_id, signal_name);
create index idx_live_data_cache_key on live_data_cache(data_key);
create index idx_live_data_cache_fetched on live_data_cache(fetched_at);
create index idx_assessments_section on assessments(section);
